2344 Returns the window system identifier of the widget, or 0 if the widget is not created yet.
2345
2346*/
2347
2348/*!
2349 \fn WId QWidget::winId() const
2350
2351 Returns the window system identifier of the widget.
2352
2353 Portable in principle, but if you use it you are probably about to
2354 do something non-portable. Be careful.
2355
2356 If a widget is non-native (alien) and winId() is invoked on it, that widget
2357 will be provided a native handle.
2358
2359 This value may change at run-time. An event with type QEvent::WinIdChange
2360 will be sent to the widget following a change in window system identifier.
2361
2362 \sa find()
2363*/
2364WId QWidget::winId() const
2365{
2366 if (!data->in_destructor
2367 && (!testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WState_Created) || !internalWinId()))
2368 {
2369 QWidget *that = const_cast<QWidget*>(this);
2370 that->setAttribute(Qt::WA_NativeWindow);
2371 that->d_func()->createWinId();
2372 return that->data->winid;
2373 }
2374 return data->winid;
2375}
2376
2377void QWidgetPrivate::createWinId()
2378{
2379 Q_Q(QWidget);
2380
2381 const bool forceNativeWindow = q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_NativeWindow);
2382 if (!q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WState_Created) || (forceNativeWindow && !q->internalWinId())) {
2383 if (!q->isWindow()) {
2384 QWidget *parent = q->parentWidget();
2385 QWidgetPrivate *pd = parent->d_func();
2386 if (forceNativeWindow && !q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_DontCreateNativeAncestors))
2387 parent->setAttribute(Qt::WA_NativeWindow);
2388 if (!parent->internalWinId()) {
2389 pd->createWinId();
2390 }
2391
2392 for (int i = 0; i < pd->children.size(); ++i) {
2393 QWidget *w = qobject_cast<QWidget *>(o: pd->children.at(i));
2394 if (w && !w->isWindow() && (!w->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WState_Created)
2395 || (!w->internalWinId() && w->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_NativeWindow)))) {
2396 w->create();
2397 }
2398 }
2399 } else {
2400 q->create();
2401 }
2402 }
2403}
2404
2405/*!
2406\internal
2407Ensures that the widget is set on the screen point is on. This is handy getting a correct
2408size hint before a resize in e.g QMenu and QToolTip.
2409Returns if the screen was changed.
2410*/
2411
2412bool QWidgetPrivate::setScreenForPoint(const QPoint &pos)
2413{
2414 Q_Q(QWidget);
2415 if (!q->isWindow())
2416 return false;
2417 // Find the screen for pos and make the widget understand it is on that screen.
2418 return setScreen(QGuiApplication::screenAt(point: pos));
2419}
2420
2421/*!
2422\internal
2423Ensures that the widget's QWindow is set to be on the given \a screen.
2424Returns true if the screen was changed.
2425*/
2426
2427bool QWidgetPrivate::setScreen(QScreen *screen)
2428{
2429 Q_Q(QWidget);
2430 if (!screen || !q->isWindow())
2431 return false;
2432 const QScreen *currentScreen = windowHandle() ? windowHandle()->screen() : nullptr;
2433 if (currentScreen != screen) {
2434 topData()->initialScreen = screen;
2435 if (windowHandle())
2436 windowHandle()->setScreen(screen);
2437 return true;
2438 }
2439 return false;
2440}
2441
2442/*!
2443\internal
2444Ensures that the widget has a window system identifier, i.e. that it is known to the windowing system.
2445
2446*/
2447
2448void QWidget::createWinId()
2449{
2450 Q_D(QWidget);
2451 d->createWinId();
2452}
2453
2454/*!
2455 \since 4.4
2456
2457 Returns the effective window system identifier of the widget, i.e. the
2458 native parent's window system identifier.
2459
2460 If the widget is native, this function returns the native widget ID.
2461 Otherwise, the window ID of the first native parent widget, i.e., the
2462 top-level widget that contains this widget, is returned.
2463
2464 \note We recommend that you do not store this value as it is likely to
2465 change at run-time.
2466
2467 \sa nativeParentWidget()
2468*/
2469WId QWidget::effectiveWinId() const
2470{
2471 const WId id = internalWinId();
2472 if (id || !testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WState_Created))
2473 return id;
2474 if (const QWidget *realParent = nativeParentWidget())
2475 return realParent->internalWinId();
2476 return 0;
2477}
2478
2479/*!
2480 If this is a native widget, return the associated QWindow.
2481 Otherwise return null.
2482
2483 Native widgets include toplevel widgets, QGLWidget, and child widgets
2484 on which winId() was called.
2485
2486 \since 5.0
2487
2488 \sa winId(), screen()
2489*/
2490QWindow *QWidget::windowHandle() const
2491{
2492 Q_D(const QWidget);
2493 return d->windowHandle();
2494}
2495
2496/*!
2497 Returns the screen the widget is on.
2498
2499 \since 5.14
2500
2501 \sa windowHandle()
2502*/
2503QScreen *QWidget::screen() const
2504{
2505 Q_D(const QWidget);
2506 if (auto associatedScreen = d->associatedScreen())
2507 return associatedScreen;
2508 if (auto topLevel = window()) {
2509 if (auto topData = qt_widget_private(widget: topLevel)->topData()) {
2510 if (topData->initialScreen)
2511 return topData->initialScreen;
2512 }
2513 if (auto screenByPos = QGuiApplication::screenAt(point: topLevel->geometry().center()))
2514 return screenByPos;
2515 }
2516 return QGuiApplication::primaryScreen();
2517}
2518
2519/*!
2520 Sets the screen on which the widget should be shown to \a screen.
2521
2522 Setting the screen only makes sense for windows. If necessary, the widget's
2523 window will get recreated on \a screen.
2524
2525 \note If the screen is part of a virtual desktop of multiple screens,
2526 the window will not move automatically to \a screen. To place the
2527 window relative to the screen, use the screen's topLeft() position.
2528
2529 \sa QWindow::setScreen()
2530*/
2531void QWidget::setScreen(QScreen *screen)
2532{
2533 Q_D(QWidget);
2534 d->setScreen(screen);
2535}
2536
2537#ifndef QT_NO_STYLE_STYLESHEET
2538
2539/*!
2540 \property QWidget::styleSheet
2541 \brief the widget's style sheet
2542 \since 4.2
2543
2544 The style sheet contains a textual description of customizations to the
2545 widget's style, as described in the \l{Qt Style Sheets} document.
2546
2547 Since Qt 4.5, Qt style sheets fully supports \macos.
2548
2549 \warning Qt style sheets are currently not supported for custom QStyle
2550 subclasses. We plan to address this in some future release.
2551
2552 \sa setStyle(), QApplication::styleSheet, {Qt Style Sheets}
2553*/
2554QString QWidget::styleSheet() const
2555{
2556 Q_D(const QWidget);
2557 if (!d->extra)
2558 return QString();
2559 return d->extra->styleSheet;
2560}
2561
2562void QWidget::setStyleSheet(const QString& styleSheet)
2563{
2564 Q_D(QWidget);
2565 if (data->in_destructor)
2566 return;
2567 d->createExtra();
2568
2569 QStyleSheetStyle *proxy = qt_styleSheet(style: d->extra->style);
2570 d->extra->styleSheet = styleSheet;
2571 if (styleSheet.isEmpty()) { // stylesheet removed
2572 if (!proxy)
2573 return;
2574
2575 d->inheritStyle();
2576 return;
2577 }
2578
2579 if (proxy) { // style sheet update
2580 bool repolish = d->polished;
2581 if (!repolish) {
2582 const auto childWidgets = findChildren<QWidget*>();
2583 for (auto child : childWidgets) {
2584 repolish = child->d_func()->polished;
2585 if (repolish)
2586 break;
2587 }
2588 }
2589 if (repolish)
2590 proxy->repolish(widget: this);
2591 return;
2592 }
2593
2594 if (testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_SetStyle)) {
2595 d->setStyle_helper(newStyle: new QStyleSheetStyle(d->extra->style), propagate: true);
2596 } else {
2597 d->setStyle_helper(newStyle: new QStyleSheetStyle(nullptr), propagate: true);
2598 }
2599}
2600
2601#endif // QT_NO_STYLE_STYLESHEET
2602
2603/*!
2604 \sa QWidget::setStyle(), QApplication::setStyle(), QApplication::style()
2605*/
2606
2607QStyle *QWidget::style() const
2608{
2609 Q_D(const QWidget);
2610
2611 if (d->extra && d->extra->style)
2612 return d->extra->style;
2613 return QApplication::style();
2614}
2615
2616/*!
2617 Sets the widget's GUI style to \a style. The ownership of the style
2618 object is not transferred.
2619
2620 If no style is set, the widget uses the application's style,
2621 QApplication::style() instead.
2622
2623 Setting a widget's style has no effect on existing or future child
2624 widgets.
2625
2626 \warning This function is particularly useful for demonstration
2627 purposes, where you want to show Qt's styling capabilities. Real
2628 applications should avoid it and use one consistent GUI style
2629 instead.
2630
2631 \warning Qt style sheets are currently not supported for custom QStyle
2632 subclasses. We plan to address this in some future release.
2633
2634 \sa style(), QStyle, QApplication::style(), QApplication::setStyle()
2635*/
2636
2637void QWidget::setStyle(QStyle *style)
2638{
2639 Q_D(QWidget);
2640 setAttribute(Qt::WA_SetStyle, on: style != nullptr);
2641 d->createExtra();
2642#ifndef QT_NO_STYLE_STYLESHEET
2643 if (QStyleSheetStyle *styleSheetStyle = qt_styleSheet(style)) {
2644 //if for some reason someone try to set a QStyleSheetStyle, ref it
2645 //(this may happen for example in QButtonDialogBox which propagates its style)
2646 styleSheetStyle->ref();
2647 d->setStyle_helper(newStyle: style, propagate: false);
2648 } else if (qt_styleSheet(style: d->extra->style) || !qApp->styleSheet().isEmpty()) {
2649 // if we have an application stylesheet or have a proxy already, propagate
2650 d->setStyle_helper(newStyle: new QStyleSheetStyle(style), propagate: true);
2651 } else
2652#endif
2653 d->setStyle_helper(newStyle: style, propagate: false);
2654}
2655
2656void QWidgetPrivate::setStyle_helper(QStyle *newStyle, bool propagate)
2657{
2658 Q_Q(QWidget);
2659 QStyle *oldStyle = q->style();
2660
2661 createExtra();
2662
2663#ifndef QT_NO_STYLE_STYLESHEET
2664 QPointer<QStyle> origStyle = extra->style;
2665#endif
2666 extra->style = newStyle;
2667
2668 // repolish
2669 if (polished && q->windowType() != Qt::Desktop) {
2670 oldStyle->unpolish(widget: q);
2671 q->style()->polish(widget: q);
2672 }
2673
2674 if (propagate) {
2675 // We copy the list because the order may be modified
2676 const QObjectList childrenList = children;
2677 for (int i = 0; i < childrenList.size(); ++i) {
2678 QWidget *c = qobject_cast<QWidget*>(o: childrenList.at(i));
2679 if (c)
2680 c->d_func()->inheritStyle();
2681 }
2682 }
2683
2684#ifndef QT_NO_STYLE_STYLESHEET
2685 if (!qt_styleSheet(style: newStyle)) {
2686 if (const QStyleSheetStyle* cssStyle = qt_styleSheet(style: origStyle)) {
2687 cssStyle->clearWidgetFont(w: q);
2688 }
2689 }
2690#endif
2691
2692 QEvent e(QEvent::StyleChange);
2693 QCoreApplication::sendEvent(receiver: q, event: &e);
2694
2695#ifndef QT_NO_STYLE_STYLESHEET
2696 // dereference the old stylesheet style
2697 if (QStyleSheetStyle *proxy = qt_styleSheet(style: origStyle))
2698 proxy->deref();
2699#endif
2700}
2701
2702// Inherits style from the current parent and propagates it as necessary
2703void QWidgetPrivate::inheritStyle()
2704{
2705#ifndef QT_NO_STYLE_STYLESHEET
2706 Q_Q(QWidget);
2707
2708 QStyle *extraStyle = extra ? (QStyle*)extra->style : nullptr;
2709
2710 QStyleSheetStyle *proxy = qt_styleSheet(style: extraStyle);
2711
2712 if (!q->styleSheet().isEmpty()) {
2713 Q_ASSERT(proxy);
2714 proxy->repolish(widget: q);
2715 return;
2716 }
2717
2718 QStyle *origStyle = proxy ? proxy->base : extraStyle;
2719 QWidget *parent = q->parentWidget();
2720 QStyle *parentStyle = (parent && parent->d_func()->extra) ? (QStyle*)parent->d_func()->extra->style : nullptr;
2721 // If we have stylesheet on app or parent has stylesheet style, we need
2722 // to be running a proxy
2723 if (!qApp->styleSheet().isEmpty() || qt_styleSheet(style: parentStyle)) {
2724 QStyle *newStyle = parentStyle;
2725 if (q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_SetStyle))
2726 newStyle = new QStyleSheetStyle(origStyle);
2727 else if (QStyleSheetStyle *newProxy = qt_styleSheet(style: parentStyle))
2728 newProxy->ref();
2729
2730 setStyle_helper(newStyle, propagate: true);
2731 return;
2732 }
2733
2734 // So, we have no stylesheet on parent/app and we have an empty stylesheet
2735 // we just need our original style back
2736 if (origStyle == extraStyle) // is it any different?
2737 return;
2738
2739 // We could have inherited the proxy from our parent (which has a custom style)
2740 // In such a case we need to start following the application style (i.e revert
2741 // the propagation behavior of QStyleSheetStyle)
2742 if (!q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_SetStyle))
2743 origStyle = nullptr;
2744
2745 setStyle_helper(newStyle: origStyle, propagate: true);
2746#endif // QT_NO_STYLE_STYLESHEET
2747}
2748
2749
2750/*!
2751 \fn bool QWidget::isWindow() const
2752
2753 Returns \c true if the widget is an independent window, otherwise
2754 returns \c false.
2755
2756 A window is a widget that isn't visually the child of any other
2757 widget and that usually has a frame and a
2758 \l{QWidget::setWindowTitle()}{window title}.
2759
2760 A window can have a \l{QWidget::parentWidget()}{parent widget}.
2761 It will then be grouped with its parent and deleted when the
2762 parent is deleted, minimized when the parent is minimized etc. If
2763 supported by the window manager, it will also have a common
2764 taskbar entry with its parent.
2765
2766 QDialog and QMainWindow widgets are by default windows, even if a
2767 parent widget is specified in the constructor. This behavior is
2768 specified by the Qt::Window flag.
2769
2770 \sa window(), isModal(), parentWidget()
2771*/
2772
2773/*!
2774 \property QWidget::modal
2775 \brief whether the widget is a modal widget
2776
2777 This property only makes sense for windows. A modal widget
2778 prevents widgets in all other windows from getting any input.
2779
2780 By default, this property is \c false.
2781
2782 \sa isWindow(), windowModality, QDialog
2783*/
2784
2785/*!
2786 \property QWidget::windowModality
2787 \brief which windows are blocked by the modal widget
2788 \since 4.1
2789
2790 This property only makes sense for windows. A modal widget
2791 prevents widgets in other windows from getting input. The value of
2792 this property controls which windows are blocked when the widget
2793 is visible. Changing this property while the window is visible has
2794 no effect; you must hide() the widget first, then show() it again.
2795
2796 By default, this property is Qt::NonModal.
2797
2798 \sa isWindow(), QWidget::modal, QDialog
2799*/
2800
2801Qt::WindowModality QWidget::windowModality() const
2802{
2803 return static_cast<Qt::WindowModality>(data->window_modality);
2804}
2805
2806void QWidget::setWindowModality(Qt::WindowModality windowModality)
2807{
2808 data->window_modality = windowModality;
2809 // setModal_sys() will be called by setAttribute()
2810 setAttribute(Qt::WA_ShowModal, on: (data->window_modality != Qt::NonModal));
2811 setAttribute(Qt::WA_SetWindowModality, on: true);
2812}
2813
2814void QWidgetPrivate::setModal_sys()
2815{
2816 Q_Q(QWidget);
2817 if (q->windowHandle())
2818 q->windowHandle()->setModality(q->windowModality());
2819}
2820
2821/*!
2822 \fn bool QWidget::underMouse() const
2823
2824 Returns \c true if the widget is under the mouse cursor; otherwise
2825 returns \c false.
2826
2827 This value is not updated properly during drag and drop
2828 operations.
2829
2830 \sa enterEvent(), leaveEvent()
2831*/
2832
2833/*!
2834 \property QWidget::minimized
2835 \brief whether this widget is minimized (iconified)
2836
2837 This property is only relevant for windows.
2838
2839 By default, this property is \c false.
2840
2841 \sa showMinimized(), visible, show(), hide(), showNormal(), maximized
2842*/
2843bool QWidget::isMinimized() const
2844{ return data->window_state & Qt::WindowMinimized; }
2845
2846/*!
2847 Shows the widget minimized, as an icon.
2848
2849 Calling this function only affects \l{isWindow()}{windows}.
2850
2851 \sa showNormal(), showMaximized(), show(), hide(), isVisible(),
2852 isMinimized()
2853*/
2854void QWidget::showMinimized()
2855{
2856 bool isMin = isMinimized();
2857 if (isMin && isVisible())
2858 return;
2859
2860 ensurePolished();
2861
2862 if (!isMin)
2863 setWindowState((windowState() & ~Qt::WindowActive) | Qt::WindowMinimized);
2864 setVisible(true);
2865}
2866
2867/*!
2868 \property QWidget::maximized
2869 \brief whether this widget is maximized
2870
2871 This property is only relevant for windows.
2872
2873 \note Due to limitations on some window systems, this does not always
2874 report the expected results (e.g., if the user on X11 maximizes the
2875 window via the window manager, Qt has no way of distinguishing this
2876 from any other resize). This is expected to improve as window manager
2877 protocols evolve.
2878
2879 By default, this property is \c false.
2880
2881 \sa windowState(), showMaximized(), visible, show(), hide(), showNormal(), minimized
2882*/
2883bool QWidget::isMaximized() const
2884{ return data->window_state & Qt::WindowMaximized; }
2885
2886
2887
2888/*!
2889 Returns the current window state. The window state is a OR'ed
2890 combination of Qt::WindowState: Qt::WindowMinimized,
2891 Qt::WindowMaximized, Qt::WindowFullScreen, and Qt::WindowActive.
2892
2893 \sa Qt::WindowState, setWindowState()
2894 */
2895Qt::WindowStates QWidget::windowState() const
2896{
2897 return Qt::WindowStates(data->window_state);
2898}
2899
2900/*!\internal
2901
2902 The function sets the window state on child widgets similar to
2903 setWindowState(). The difference is that the window state changed
2904 event has the isOverride() flag set. It exists mainly to keep
2905 QWorkspace working.
2906 */
2907void QWidget::overrideWindowState(Qt::WindowStates newstate)
2908{
2909 QWindowStateChangeEvent e(Qt::WindowStates(data->window_state), true);
2910 data->window_state = newstate;
2911 QCoreApplication::sendEvent(receiver: this, event: &e);
2912}
2913
2914/*!
2915 \fn void QWidget::setWindowState(Qt::WindowStates windowState)
2916
2917 Sets the window state to \a windowState. The window state is a OR'ed
2918 combination of Qt::WindowState: Qt::WindowMinimized,
2919 Qt::WindowMaximized, Qt::WindowFullScreen, and Qt::WindowActive.
2920
2921 If the window is not visible (i.e. isVisible() returns \c false), the
2922 window state will take effect when show() is called. For visible
2923 windows, the change is immediate. For example, to toggle between
2924 full-screen and normal mode, use the following code:
2925
2926 \snippet code/src_gui_kernel_qwidget.cpp 0
2927
2928 In order to restore and activate a minimized window (while
2929 preserving its maximized and/or full-screen state), use the following:
2930
2931 \snippet code/src_gui_kernel_qwidget.cpp 1
2932
2933 Calling this function will hide the widget. You must call show() to make
2934 the widget visible again.
2935
2936 \note On some window systems Qt::WindowActive is not immediate, and may be
2937 ignored in certain cases.
2938
2939 When the window state changes, the widget receives a changeEvent()
2940 of type QEvent::WindowStateChange.
2941
2942 \sa Qt::WindowState, windowState()
2943*/
2944void QWidget::setWindowState(Qt::WindowStates newstate)
2945{
2946 Q_D(QWidget);
2947 Qt::WindowStates oldstate = windowState();
2948 if (newstate.testFlag(flag: Qt::WindowMinimized)) // QTBUG-46763
2949 newstate.setFlag(flag: Qt::WindowActive, on: false);
2950 if (oldstate == newstate)
2951 return;
2952 if (isWindow() && !testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WState_Created))
2953 create();
2954
2955 data->window_state = newstate;
2956 data->in_set_window_state = 1;
2957 if (isWindow()) {
2958 // Ensure the initial size is valid, since we store it as normalGeometry below.
2959 if (!testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_Resized) && !isVisible())
2960 adjustSize();
2961
2962 d->createTLExtra();
2963 if (!(oldstate & (Qt::WindowMinimized | Qt::WindowMaximized | Qt::WindowFullScreen)))
2964 d->topData()->normalGeometry = geometry();
2965
2966 Q_ASSERT(windowHandle());
2967 windowHandle()->setWindowStates(newstate & ~Qt::WindowActive);
2968 }
2969 data->in_set_window_state = 0;
2970
2971 if (newstate & Qt::WindowActive)
2972 activateWindow();
2973
2974 QWindowStateChangeEvent e(oldstate);
2975 QCoreApplication::sendEvent(receiver: this, event: &e);
2976}
2977
2978/*!
2979 \property QWidget::fullScreen
2980 \brief whether the widget is shown in full screen mode
2981
2982 A widget in full screen mode occupies the whole screen area and does not
2983 display window decorations, such as a title bar.
2984
2985 By default, this property is \c false.
2986
2987 \sa windowState(), minimized, maximized
2988*/
2989bool QWidget::isFullScreen() const
2990{ return data->window_state & Qt::WindowFullScreen; }
2991
2992/*!
2993 Shows the widget in full-screen mode.
2994
2995 Calling this function only affects \l{isWindow()}{windows}.
2996
2997 To return from full-screen mode, call showNormal() or close().
2998
2999 \note Full-screen mode works fine under Windows, but has certain
3000 problems under X. These problems are due to limitations of the
3001 ICCCM protocol that specifies the communication between X11
3002 clients and the window manager. ICCCM simply does not understand
3003 the concept of non-decorated full-screen windows. Therefore, the
3004 best we can do is to request a borderless window and place and
3005 resize it to fill the entire screen. Depending on the window
3006 manager, this may or may not work. The borderless window is
3007 requested using MOTIF hints, which are at least partially
3008 supported by virtually all modern window managers.
3009
3010 An alternative would be to bypass the window manager entirely and
3011 create a window with the Qt::X11BypassWindowManagerHint flag. This
3012 has other severe problems though, like totally broken keyboard focus
3013 and very strange effects on desktop changes or when the user raises
3014 other windows.
3015
3016 X11 window managers that follow modern post-ICCCM specifications
3017 support full-screen mode properly.
3018
3019 On macOS, showing a window full screen puts the entire application in
3020 full-screen mode, providing it with a dedicated desktop. Showing another
3021 window while the application runs in full-screen mode might automatically
3022 make that window full screen as well. To prevent that, exit full-screen
3023 mode by calling showNormal() or by close() on the full screen window
3024 before showing another window.
3025
3026 \sa showNormal(), showMaximized(), show(), isVisible(), close()
3027*/
3028void QWidget::showFullScreen()
3029{
3030 ensurePolished();
3031
3032 setWindowState((windowState() & ~(Qt::WindowMinimized | Qt::WindowMaximized))
3033 | Qt::WindowFullScreen);
3034 setVisible(true);
3035#if !defined Q_OS_QNX // On QNX this window will be activated anyway from libscreen
3036 // activating it here before libscreen activates it causes problems
3037 activateWindow();
3038#endif
3039}
3040
3041/*!
3042 Shows the widget maximized.
3043
3044 Calling this function only affects \l{isWindow()}{windows}.
3045
3046 On X11, this function may not work properly with certain window
3047 managers. See the \l{Window Geometry} documentation for an explanation.
3048
3049 \sa setWindowState(), showNormal(), showMinimized(), show(), hide(), isVisible()
3050*/
3051void QWidget::showMaximized()
3052{
3053 ensurePolished();
3054
3055 setWindowState((windowState() & ~(Qt::WindowMinimized | Qt::WindowFullScreen))
3056 | Qt::WindowMaximized);
3057 setVisible(true);
3058}
3059
3060/*!
3061 Restores the widget after it has been maximized or minimized.
3062
3063 Calling this function only affects \l{isWindow()}{windows}.
3064
3065 \sa setWindowState(), showMinimized(), showMaximized(), show(), hide(), isVisible()
3066*/
3067void QWidget::showNormal()
3068{
3069 ensurePolished();
3070
3071 setWindowState(windowState() & ~(Qt::WindowMinimized
3072 | Qt::WindowMaximized
3073 | Qt::WindowFullScreen));
3074 setVisible(true);
3075}
3076
3077/*!
3078 Returns \c true if this widget would become enabled if \a ancestor is
3079 enabled; otherwise returns \c false.
3080
3081
3082
3083 This is the case if neither the widget itself nor every parent up
3084 to but excluding \a ancestor has been explicitly disabled.
3085
3086 isEnabledTo(0) returns false if this widget or any if its ancestors
3087 was explicitly disabled.
3088
3089 The word ancestor here means a parent widget within the same window.
3090
3091 Therefore isEnabledTo(0) stops at this widget's window, unlike
3092 isEnabled() which also takes parent windows into considerations.
3093
3094 \sa setEnabled(), enabled
3095*/
3096
3097bool QWidget::isEnabledTo(const QWidget *ancestor) const
3098{
3099 const QWidget * w = this;
3100 while (!w->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_ForceDisabled)
3101 && !w->isWindow()
3102 && w->parentWidget()
3103 && w->parentWidget() != ancestor)
3104 w = w->parentWidget();
3105 return !w->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_ForceDisabled);
3106}
3107
3108#ifndef QT_NO_ACTION
3109/*!
3110 Appends the action \a action to this widget's list of actions.
3111
3112 All QWidgets have a list of \l{QAction}s, however they can be
3113 represented graphically in many different ways. The default use of
3114 the QAction list (as returned by actions()) is to create a context
3115 QMenu.
3116
3117 A QWidget should only have one of each action and adding an action
3118 it already has will not cause the same action to be in the widget twice.
3119
3120 The ownership of \a action is not transferred to this QWidget.
3121
3122 \sa removeAction(), insertAction(), actions(), QMenu
3123*/
3124void QWidget::addAction(QAction *action)
3125{
3126 insertAction(before: nullptr, action);
3127}
3128
3129/*!
3130 Appends the actions \a actions to this widget's list of actions.
3131
3132 \sa removeAction(), QMenu, addAction()
3133*/
3134void QWidget::addActions(const QList<QAction *> &actions)
3135{
3136 for(int i = 0; i < actions.size(); i++)
3137 insertAction(before: nullptr, action: actions.at(i));
3138}
3139
3140/*!
3141 Inserts the action \a action to this widget's list of actions,
3142 before the action \a before. It appends the action if \a before is \nullptr or
3143 \a before is not a valid action for this widget.
3144
3145 A QWidget should only have one of each action.
3146
3147 \sa removeAction(), addAction(), QMenu, contextMenuPolicy, actions()
3148*/
3149void QWidget::insertAction(QAction *before, QAction *action)
3150{
3151 if (Q_UNLIKELY(!action)) {
3152 qWarning(msg: "QWidget::insertAction: Attempt to insert null action");
3153 return;
3154 }
3155
3156 Q_D(QWidget);
3157 if (d->actions.contains(t: action))
3158 removeAction(action);
3159
3160 int pos = d->actions.indexOf(t: before);
3161 if (pos < 0) {
3162 before = nullptr;
3163 pos = d->actions.size();
3164 }
3165 d->actions.insert(i: pos, t: action);
3166
3167 QActionPrivate *apriv = action->d_func();
3168 apriv->associatedObjects.append(t: this);
3169
3170 QActionEvent e(QEvent::ActionAdded, action, before);
3171 QCoreApplication::sendEvent(receiver: this, event: &e);
3172}
3173
3174/*!
3175 Inserts the actions \a actions to this widget's list of actions,
3176 before the action \a before. It appends the action if \a before is \nullptr or
3177 \a before is not a valid action for this widget.
3178
3179 A QWidget can have at most one of each action.
3180
3181 \sa removeAction(), QMenu, insertAction(), contextMenuPolicy
3182*/
3183void QWidget::insertActions(QAction *before, const QList<QAction*> &actions)
3184{
3185 for(int i = 0; i < actions.size(); ++i)
3186 insertAction(before, action: actions.at(i));
3187}
3188
3189/*!
3190 Removes the action \a action from this widget's list of actions.
3191 \sa insertAction(), actions(), insertAction()
3192*/
3193void QWidget::removeAction(QAction *action)
3194{
3195 if (!action)
3196 return;
3197
3198 Q_D(QWidget);
3199
3200 QActionPrivate *apriv = action->d_func();
3201 apriv->associatedObjects.removeAll(t: this);
3202
3203 if (d->actions.removeAll(t: action)) {
3204 QActionEvent e(QEvent::ActionRemoved, action);
3205 QCoreApplication::sendEvent(receiver: this, event: &e);
3206 }
3207}
3208
3209/*!
3210 Returns the (possibly empty) list of this widget's actions.
3211
3212 \sa contextMenuPolicy, insertAction(), removeAction()
3213*/
3214QList<QAction*> QWidget::actions() const
3215{
3216 Q_D(const QWidget);
3217 return d->actions;
3218}
3219
3220/*!
3221 \fn QAction *QWidget::addAction(const QString &text);
3222 \fn QAction *QWidget::addAction(const QString &text, const QKeySequence &shortcut);
3223 \fn QAction *QWidget::addAction(const QIcon &icon, const QString &text);
3224 \fn QAction *QWidget::addAction(const QIcon &icon, const QString &text, const QKeySequence &shortcut);
3225
3226 \since 6.3
3227
3228 These convenience functions create a new action with text \a text,
3229 icon \a icon and shortcut \a shortcut, if any.
3230
3231 The functions add the newly created action to the widget's
3232 list of actions, and return it.
3233
3234 QWidget takes ownership of the returned QAction.
3235*/
3236QAction *QWidget::addAction(const QString &text)
3237{
3238 QAction *ret = new QAction(text, this);
3239 addAction(action: ret);
3240 return ret;
3241}
3242
3243QAction *QWidget::addAction(const QIcon &icon, const QString &text)
3244{
3245 QAction *ret = new QAction(icon, text, this);
3246 addAction(action: ret);
3247 return ret;
3248}
3249
3250#if QT_CONFIG(shortcut)
3251QAction *QWidget::addAction(const QString &text, const QKeySequence &shortcut)
3252{
3253 QAction *ret = addAction(text);
3254 ret->setShortcut(shortcut);
3255 return ret;
3256}
3257
3258QAction *QWidget::addAction(const QIcon &icon, const QString &text, const QKeySequence &shortcut)
3259{
3260 QAction *ret = addAction(icon, text);
3261 ret->setShortcut(shortcut);
3262 return ret;
3263}
3264#endif
3265
3266/*!
3267 \fn QAction *QWidget::addAction(const QString &text, const QObject *receiver, const char* member, Qt::ConnectionType type)
3268 \fn QAction *QWidget::addAction(const QIcon &icon, const QString &text, const QObject *receiver, const char* member, Qt::ConnectionType type)
3269 \fn QAction *QWidget::addAction(const QString &text, const QKeySequence &shortcut, const QObject *receiver, const char* member, Qt::ConnectionType type)
3270 \fn QAction *QWidget::addAction(const QIcon &icon, const QString &text, const QKeySequence &shortcut, const QObject *receiver, const char* member, Qt::ConnectionType type)
3271
3272 \overload
3273 \since 6.3
3274
3275 This convenience function creates a new action with the text \a
3276 text, icon \a icon, and shortcut \a shortcut, if any.
3277
3278 The action's \l{QAction::triggered()}{triggered()} signal is connected
3279 to the \a receiver's \a member slot. The function adds the newly created
3280 action to the widget's list of actions and returns it.
3281
3282 QWidget takes ownership of the returned QAction.
3283*/
3284QAction *QWidget::addAction(const QString &text, const QObject *receiver, const char* member,
3285 Qt::ConnectionType type)
3286{
3287 QAction *action = addAction(text);
3288 QObject::connect(sender: action, SIGNAL(triggered(bool)), receiver, member, type);
3289 return action;
3290}
3291
3292QAction *QWidget::addAction(const QIcon &icon, const QString &text,
3293 const QObject *receiver, const char* member,
3294 Qt::ConnectionType type)
3295{
3296 QAction *action = addAction(icon, text);
3297 QObject::connect(sender: action, SIGNAL(triggered(bool)), receiver, member, type);
3298 return action;
3299}
3300
3301#if QT_CONFIG(shortcut)
3302QAction *QWidget::addAction(const QString &text, const QKeySequence &shortcut,
3303 const QObject *receiver, const char* member,
3304 Qt::ConnectionType type)
3305{
3306 QAction *action = addAction(text, receiver, member, type);
3307 action->setShortcut(shortcut);
3308 return action;
3309}
3310
3311QAction *QWidget::addAction(const QIcon &icon, const QString &text, const QKeySequence &shortcut,
3312 const QObject *receiver, const char* member,
3313 Qt::ConnectionType type)
3314{
3315 QAction *action = addAction(icon, text, receiver, member, type);
3316 action->setShortcut(shortcut);
3317 return action;
3318}
3319#endif // QT_CONFIG(shortcut)
3320
3321/*!
3322 \fn template<typename...Args> QAction *QWidget::addAction(const QString &text, Args&&...args)
3323 \fn template<typename...Args> QAction *QWidget::addAction(const QString &text, const QKeySequence &shortcut, Args&&...args)
3324 \fn template<typename...Args> QAction *QWidget::addAction(const QIcon &icon, const QString &text, Args&&...args)
3325 \fn template<typename...Args> QAction *QWidget::addAction(const QIcon &icon, const QString &text, const QKeySequence &shortcut, Args&&...args)
3326
3327 \since 6.3
3328 \overload
3329
3330 These convenience functions create a new action with the text \a text,
3331 icon \a icon, and shortcut \a shortcut, if any.
3332
3333 The action's \l{QAction::triggered()}{triggered()} signal is connected
3334 as if by a call to QObject::connect(action, &QAction::triggered, args...),
3335 perfectly forwarding \a args, including a possible Qt::ConnectionType.
3336
3337 The function adds the newly created action to the widget's list of
3338 actions and returns it.
3339
3340 QWidget takes ownership of the returned QAction.
3341*/
3342#endif // QT_NO_ACTION
3343
3344/*!
3345 \property QWidget::enabled
3346 \brief whether the widget is enabled
3347
3348 In general an enabled widget handles keyboard and mouse events; a disabled
3349 widget does not. An exception is made with \l{QAbstractButton}.
3350
3351 Some widgets display themselves differently when they are
3352 disabled. For example a button might draw its label grayed out. If
3353 your widget needs to know when it becomes enabled or disabled, you
3354 can use the changeEvent() with type QEvent::EnabledChange.
3355
3356 Disabling a widget implicitly disables all its children. Enabling
3357 respectively enables all child widgets unless they have been
3358 explicitly disabled. It it not possible to explicitly enable a child
3359 widget which is not a window while its parent widget remains disabled.
3360
3361 By default, this property is \c true.
3362
3363 \sa isEnabledTo(), QKeyEvent, QMouseEvent, changeEvent()
3364*/
3365void QWidget::setEnabled(bool enable)
3366{
3367 Q_D(QWidget);
3368 setAttribute(Qt::WA_ForceDisabled, on: !enable);
3369 d->setEnabled_helper(enable);
3370}
3371
3372void QWidgetPrivate::setEnabled_helper(bool enable)
3373{
3374 Q_Q(QWidget);
3375
3376 if (enable && !q->isWindow() && q->parentWidget() && !q->parentWidget()->isEnabled())
3377 return; // nothing we can do
3378
3379 if (enable != q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_Disabled))
3380 return; // nothing to do
3381
3382 q->setAttribute(Qt::WA_Disabled, on: !enable);
3383 updateSystemBackground();
3384
3385 if (!enable && q->window()->focusWidget() == q) {
3386 bool parentIsEnabled = (!q->parentWidget() || q->parentWidget()->isEnabled());
3387 if (!parentIsEnabled || !q->focusNextChild())
3388 q->clearFocus();
3389 }
3390
3391 Qt::WidgetAttribute attribute = enable ? Qt::WA_ForceDisabled : Qt::WA_Disabled;
3392 for (int i = 0; i < children.size(); ++i) {
3393 QWidget *w = qobject_cast<QWidget *>(o: children.at(i));
3394 if (w && !w->testAttribute(attribute))
3395 w->d_func()->setEnabled_helper(enable);
3396 }
3397#ifndef QT_NO_CURSOR
3398 if (q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_SetCursor) || q->isWindow()) {
3399 // enforce the windows behavior of clearing the cursor on
3400 // disabled widgets
3401 qt_qpa_set_cursor(w: q, force: false);
3402 }
3403#endif
3404#ifndef QT_NO_IM
3405 if (q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_InputMethodEnabled) && q->hasFocus()) {
3406 QWidget *focusWidget = effectiveFocusWidget();
3407
3408 if (enable) {
3409 if (focusWidget->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_InputMethodEnabled))
3410 QGuiApplication::inputMethod()->update(queries: Qt::ImEnabled);
3411 } else {
3412 QGuiApplication::inputMethod()->commit();
3413 QGuiApplication::inputMethod()->update(queries: Qt::ImEnabled);
3414 }
3415 }
3416#endif //QT_NO_IM
3417 QEvent e(QEvent::EnabledChange);
3418 QCoreApplication::sendEvent(receiver: q, event: &e);
3419}
3420
3421/*!
3422 \property QWidget::acceptDrops
3423 \brief whether drop events are enabled for this widget
3424
3425 Setting this property to true announces to the system that this
3426 widget \e may be able to accept drop events.
3427
3428 If the widget is the desktop (windowType() == Qt::Desktop), this may
3429 fail if another application is using the desktop; you can call
3430 acceptDrops() to test if this occurs.
3431
3432 \warning Do not modify this property in a drag and drop event handler.
3433
3434 By default, this property is \c false.
3435
3436 \sa {Drag and Drop in Qt}{Drag and Drop}
3437*/
3438bool QWidget::acceptDrops() const
3439{
3440 return testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_AcceptDrops);
3441}
3442
3443void QWidget::setAcceptDrops(bool on)
3444{
3445 setAttribute(Qt::WA_AcceptDrops, on);
3446
3447}
3448
3449/*!
3450 Disables widget input events if \a disable is true; otherwise
3451 enables input events.
3452
3453 See the \l enabled documentation for more information.
3454
3455 \sa isEnabledTo(), QKeyEvent, QMouseEvent, changeEvent()
3456*/
3457void QWidget::setDisabled(bool disable)
3458{
3459 setEnabled(!disable);
3460}
3461
3462/*!
3463 \property QWidget::frameGeometry
3464 \brief geometry of the widget relative to its parent including any
3465 window frame
3466
3467 See the \l{Window Geometry} documentation for an overview of geometry
3468 issues with windows.
3469
3470 By default, this property contains a value that depends on the user's
3471 platform and screen geometry.
3472
3473 \sa geometry(), x(), y(), pos()
3474*/
3475QRect QWidget::frameGeometry() const
3476{
3477 Q_D(const QWidget);
3478 if (isWindow() && ! (windowType() == Qt::Popup)) {
3479 QRect fs = d->frameStrut();
3480 return QRect(data->crect.x() - fs.left(),
3481 data->crect.y() - fs.top(),
3482 data->crect.width() + fs.left() + fs.right(),
3483 data->crect.height() + fs.top() + fs.bottom());
3484 }
3485 return data->crect;
3486}
3487
3488/*!
3489 \property QWidget::x
3490
3491 \brief the x coordinate of the widget relative to its parent including
3492 any window frame
3493
3494 See the \l{Window Geometry} documentation for an overview of geometry
3495 issues with windows.
3496
3497 By default, this property has a value of 0.
3498
3499 \sa frameGeometry, y, pos
3500*/
3501int QWidget::x() const
3502{
3503 Q_D(const QWidget);
3504 if (isWindow() && ! (windowType() == Qt::Popup))
3505 return data->crect.x() - d->frameStrut().left();
3506 return data->crect.x();
3507}
3508
3509/*!
3510 \property QWidget::y
3511 \brief the y coordinate of the widget relative to its parent and
3512 including any window frame
3513
3514 See the \l{Window Geometry} documentation for an overview of geometry
3515 issues with windows.
3516
3517 By default, this property has a value of 0.
3518
3519 \sa frameGeometry, x, pos
3520*/
3521int QWidget::y() const
3522{
3523 Q_D(const QWidget);
3524 if (isWindow() && ! (windowType() == Qt::Popup))
3525 return data->crect.y() - d->frameStrut().top();
3526 return data->crect.y();
3527}
3528
3529/*!
3530 \property QWidget::pos
3531 \brief the position of the widget within its parent widget
3532
3533 If the widget is a window, the position is that of the widget on
3534 the desktop, including its frame.
3535
3536 When changing the position, the widget, if visible, receives a
3537 move event (moveEvent()) immediately. If the widget is not
3538 currently visible, it is guaranteed to receive an event before it
3539 is shown.
3540
3541 By default, this property contains a position that refers to the
3542 origin.
3543
3544 \warning Calling move() or setGeometry() inside moveEvent() can
3545 lead to infinite recursion.
3546
3547 See the \l{Window Geometry} documentation for an overview of geometry
3548 issues with windows.
3549
3550 \sa frameGeometry, size, x(), y()
3551*/
3552QPoint QWidget::pos() const
3553{
3554 Q_D(const QWidget);
3555 QPoint result = data->crect.topLeft();
3556 if (isWindow() && ! (windowType() == Qt::Popup))
3557 if (!d->maybeTopData() || !d->maybeTopData()->posIncludesFrame)
3558 result -= d->frameStrut().topLeft();
3559 return result;
3560}
3561
3562/*!
3563 \property QWidget::geometry
3564 \brief the geometry of the widget relative to its parent and
3565 excluding the window frame
3566
3567 When changing the geometry, the widget, if visible, receives a
3568 move event (moveEvent()) and/or a resize event (resizeEvent())
3569 immediately. If the widget is not currently visible, it is
3570 guaranteed to receive appropriate events before it is shown.
3571
3572 The size component is adjusted if it lies outside the range
3573 defined by minimumSize() and maximumSize().
3574
3575 \warning Calling setGeometry() inside resizeEvent() or moveEvent()
3576 can lead to infinite recursion.
3577
3578 See the \l{Window Geometry} documentation for an overview of geometry
3579 issues with windows.
3580
3581 By default, this property contains a value that depends on the user's
3582 platform and screen geometry.
3583
3584 \sa frameGeometry(), rect(), move(), resize(), moveEvent(),
3585 resizeEvent(), minimumSize(), maximumSize()
3586*/
3587
3588/*!
3589 \property QWidget::size
3590 \brief the size of the widget excluding any window frame
3591
3592 If the widget is visible when it is being resized, it receives a resize event
3593 (resizeEvent()) immediately. If the widget is not currently
3594 visible, it is guaranteed to receive an event before it is shown.
3595
3596 The size is adjusted if it lies outside the range defined by
3597 minimumSize() and maximumSize().
3598
3599 By default, this property contains a value that depends on the user's
3600 platform and screen geometry.
3601
3602 \warning Calling resize() or setGeometry() inside resizeEvent() can
3603 lead to infinite recursion.
3604
3605 \note Setting the size to \c{QSize(0, 0)} will cause the widget to not
3606 appear on screen. This also applies to windows.
3607
3608 \sa pos, geometry, minimumSize, maximumSize, resizeEvent(), adjustSize()
3609*/
3610
3611/*!
3612 \property QWidget::width
3613 \brief the width of the widget excluding any window frame
3614
3615 See the \l{Window Geometry} documentation for an overview of geometry
3616 issues with windows.
3617
3618 \note Do not use this function to find the width of a screen on
3619 a multi-screen desktop. See QScreen for details.
3620
3621 By default, this property contains a value that depends on the user's
3622 platform and screen geometry.
3623
3624 \sa geometry, height, size
3625*/
3626
3627/*!
3628 \property QWidget::height
3629 \brief the height of the widget excluding any window frame
3630
3631 See the \l{Window Geometry} documentation for an overview of geometry
3632 issues with windows.
3633
3634 By default, this property contains a value that depends on the user's
3635 platform and \l{QScreen::geometry}{screen geometry}.
3636
3637 \sa geometry, width, size
3638*/
3639
3640/*!
3641 \property QWidget::rect
3642 \brief the internal geometry of the widget excluding any window
3643 frame
3644
3645 The rect property equals QRect(0, 0, width(), height()).
3646
3647 See the \l{Window Geometry} documentation for an overview of geometry
3648 issues with windows.
3649
3650 By default, this property contains a value that depends on the user's
3651 platform and screen geometry.
3652
3653 \sa size
3654*/
3655
3656/*!
3657 \property QWidget::normalGeometry
3658
3659 \brief the geometry of the widget as it will appear when shown as
3660 a normal (not maximized or full screen) top-level widget
3661
3662 If the widget is already in this state the normal geometry will
3663 reflect the widget's current geometry().
3664
3665 For child widgets this property always holds an empty rectangle.
3666
3667 By default, this property contains an empty rectangle.
3668
3669 \sa QWidget::windowState(), QWidget::geometry
3670*/
3671QRect QWidget::normalGeometry() const
3672{
3673 Q_D(const QWidget);
3674 if (!isWindow())
3675 return QRect();
3676
3677 if (!isMaximized() && !isFullScreen())
3678 return geometry();
3679
3680 return d->topData()->normalGeometry;
3681}
3682
3683
3684/*!
3685 \property QWidget::childrenRect
3686 \brief the bounding rectangle of the widget's children
3687
3688 Hidden children are excluded.
3689
3690 By default, for a widget with no children, this property contains a
3691 rectangle with zero width and height located at the origin.
3692
3693 \sa childrenRegion(), geometry()
3694*/
3695
3696QRect QWidget::childrenRect() const
3697{
3698 Q_D(const QWidget);
3699 QRect r(0, 0, 0, 0);
3700 for (int i = 0; i < d->children.size(); ++i) {
3701 QWidget *w = qobject_cast<QWidget *>(o: d->children.at(i));
3702 if (w && !w->isWindow() && !w->isHidden())
3703 r |= w->geometry();
3704 }
3705 return r;
3706}
3707
3708/*!
3709 \property QWidget::childrenRegion
3710 \brief the combined region occupied by the widget's children
3711
3712 Hidden children are excluded.
3713
3714 By default, for a widget with no children, this property contains an
3715 empty region.
3716
3717 \sa childrenRect(), geometry(), mask()
3718*/
3719
3720QRegion QWidget::childrenRegion() const
3721{
3722 Q_D(const QWidget);
3723 QRegion r;
3724 for (int i = 0; i < d->children.size(); ++i) {
3725 QWidget *w = qobject_cast<QWidget *>(o: d->children.at(i));
3726 if (w && !w->isWindow() && !w->isHidden()) {
3727 QRegion mask = w->mask();
3728 if (mask.isEmpty())
3729 r |= w->geometry();
3730 else
3731 r |= mask.translated(p: w->pos());
3732 }
3733 }
3734 return r;
3735}
3736
3737
3738/*!
3739 \property QWidget::minimumSize
3740 \brief the widget's minimum size
3741
3742 The widget cannot be resized to a smaller size than the minimum
3743 widget size. The widget's size is forced to the minimum size if
3744 the current size is smaller.
3745
3746 The minimum size set by this function will override the minimum size
3747 defined by QLayout. In order to unset the minimum size, use a
3748 value of \c{QSize(0, 0)}.
3749
3750 By default, this property contains a size with zero width and height.
3751
3752 \sa minimumWidth, minimumHeight, maximumSize, sizeIncrement
3753*/
3754
3755QSize QWidget::minimumSize() const
3756{
3757 Q_D(const QWidget);
3758 return d->extra ? QSize(d->extra->minw, d->extra->minh) : QSize(0, 0);
3759}
3760
3761/*!
3762 \property QWidget::maximumSize
3763 \brief the widget's maximum size in pixels
3764
3765 The widget cannot be resized to a larger size than the maximum
3766 widget size.
3767
3768 By default, this property contains a size in which both width and height
3769 have values of 16777215.
3770
3771 \note The definition of the \c QWIDGETSIZE_MAX macro limits the maximum size
3772 of widgets.
3773
3774 \sa maximumWidth, maximumHeight, minimumSize, sizeIncrement
3775*/
3776
3777QSize QWidget::maximumSize() const
3778{
3779 Q_D(const QWidget);
3780 return d->extra ? QSize(d->extra->maxw, d->extra->maxh)
3781 : QSize(QWIDGETSIZE_MAX, QWIDGETSIZE_MAX);
3782}
3783
3784
3785/*!
3786 \property QWidget::minimumWidth
3787 \brief the widget's minimum width in pixels
3788
3789 This property corresponds to the width held by the \l minimumSize property.
3790
3791 By default, this property has a value of 0.
3792
3793 \sa minimumSize, minimumHeight
3794*/
3795
3796/*!
3797 \property QWidget::minimumHeight
3798 \brief the widget's minimum height in pixels
3799
3800 This property corresponds to the height held by the \l minimumSize property.
3801
3802 By default, this property has a value of 0.
3803
3804 \sa minimumSize, minimumWidth
3805*/
3806
3807/*!
3808 \property QWidget::maximumWidth
3809 \brief the widget's maximum width in pixels
3810
3811 This property corresponds to the width held by the \l maximumSize property.
3812
3813 By default, this property contains a value of 16777215.
3814
3815 \note The definition of the \c QWIDGETSIZE_MAX macro limits the maximum size
3816 of widgets.
3817
3818 \sa maximumSize, maximumHeight
3819*/
3820
3821/*!
3822 \property QWidget::maximumHeight
3823 \brief the widget's maximum height in pixels
3824
3825 This property corresponds to the height held by the \l maximumSize property.
3826
3827 By default, this property contains a value of 16777215.
3828
3829 \note The definition of the \c QWIDGETSIZE_MAX macro limits the maximum size
3830 of widgets.
3831
3832 \sa maximumSize, maximumWidth
3833*/
3834
3835/*!
3836 \property QWidget::sizeIncrement
3837 \brief the size increment of the widget
3838
3839 When the user resizes the window, the size will move in steps of
3840 sizeIncrement().width() pixels horizontally and
3841 sizeIncrement.height() pixels vertically, with baseSize() as the
3842 basis. Preferred widget sizes are for non-negative integers \e i
3843 and \e j:
3844 \snippet code/src_gui_kernel_qwidget.cpp 2
3845
3846 Note that while you can set the size increment for all widgets, it
3847 only affects windows.
3848
3849 By default, this property contains a size with zero width and height.
3850
3851 \warning The size increment has no effect under Windows, and may
3852 be disregarded by the window manager on X11.
3853
3854 \sa size, minimumSize, maximumSize
3855*/
3856QSize QWidget::sizeIncrement() const
3857{
3858 Q_D(const QWidget);
3859 return (d->extra && d->extra->topextra)
3860 ? QSize(d->extra->topextra->incw, d->extra->topextra->inch)
3861 : QSize(0, 0);
3862}
3863
3864/*!
3865 \property QWidget::baseSize
3866 \brief the base size of the widget
3867
3868 The base size is used to calculate a proper widget size if the
3869 widget defines sizeIncrement().
3870
3871 By default, for a newly-created widget, this property contains a size with
3872 zero width and height.
3873
3874 \sa setSizeIncrement()
3875*/
3876
3877QSize QWidget::baseSize() const
3878{
3879 Q_D(const QWidget);
3880 return (d->extra && d->extra->topextra)
3881 ? QSize(d->extra->topextra->basew, d->extra->topextra->baseh)
3882 : QSize(0, 0);
3883}
3884
3885bool QWidgetPrivate::setMinimumSize_helper(int &minw, int &minh)
3886{
3887 Q_Q(QWidget);
3888
3889 int mw = minw, mh = minh;
3890 if (mw == QWIDGETSIZE_MAX)
3891 mw = 0;
3892 if (mh == QWIDGETSIZE_MAX)
3893 mh = 0;
3894 if (Q_UNLIKELY(minw > QWIDGETSIZE_MAX || minh > QWIDGETSIZE_MAX)) {
3895 qWarning(msg: "QWidget::setMinimumSize: (%s/%s) "
3896 "The largest allowed size is (%d,%d)",
3897 q->objectName().toLocal8Bit().data(), q->metaObject()->className(), QWIDGETSIZE_MAX,
3898 QWIDGETSIZE_MAX);
3899 minw = mw = qMin<int>(a: minw, QWIDGETSIZE_MAX);
3900 minh = mh = qMin<int>(a: minh, QWIDGETSIZE_MAX);
3901 }
3902 if (Q_UNLIKELY(minw < 0 || minh < 0)) {
3903 qWarning(msg: "QWidget::setMinimumSize: (%s/%s) Negative sizes (%d,%d) "
3904 "are not possible",
3905 q->objectName().toLocal8Bit().data(), q->metaObject()->className(), minw, minh);
3906 minw = mw = qMax(a: minw, b: 0);
3907 minh = mh = qMax(a: minh, b: 0);
3908 }
3909 createExtra();
3910 if (extra->minw == mw && extra->minh == mh)
3911 return false;
3912 extra->minw = mw;
3913 extra->minh = mh;
3914 extra->explicitMinSize = (mw ? Qt::Horizontal : 0) | (mh ? Qt::Vertical : 0);
3915 return true;
3916}
3917
3918void QWidgetPrivate::setConstraints_sys()
3919{
3920 Q_Q(QWidget);
3921 if (extra && q->windowHandle()) {
3922 QWindow *win = q->windowHandle();
3923 QWindowPrivate *winp = qt_window_private(window: win);
3924
3925 winp->minimumSize = QSize(extra->minw, extra->minh);
3926 winp->maximumSize = QSize(extra->maxw, extra->maxh);
3927
3928 if (extra->topextra) {
3929 winp->baseSize = QSize(extra->topextra->basew, extra->topextra->baseh);
3930 winp->sizeIncrement = QSize(extra->topextra->incw, extra->topextra->inch);
3931 }
3932
3933 if (winp->platformWindow) {
3934 fixPosIncludesFrame();
3935 winp->platformWindow->propagateSizeHints();
3936 }
3937 }
3938}
3939
3940/*!
3941 \overload
3942
3943 This function corresponds to setMinimumSize(QSize(minw, minh)).
3944 Sets the minimum width to \a minw and the minimum height to \a
3945 minh.
3946*/
3947
3948void QWidget::setMinimumSize(int minw, int minh)
3949{
3950 Q_D(QWidget);
3951 if (!d->setMinimumSize_helper(minw, minh))
3952 return;
3953
3954 if (isWindow())
3955 d->setConstraints_sys();
3956 if (minw > width() || minh > height()) {
3957 bool resized = testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_Resized);
3958 bool maximized = isMaximized();
3959 resize(w: qMax(a: minw,b: width()), h: qMax(a: minh,b: height()));
3960 setAttribute(Qt::WA_Resized, on: resized); //not a user resize
3961 if (maximized)
3962 data->window_state = data->window_state | Qt::WindowMaximized;
3963 }
3964#if QT_CONFIG(graphicsview)
3965 if (d->extra) {
3966 if (d->extra->proxyWidget)
3967 d->extra->proxyWidget->setMinimumSize(aw: minw, ah: minh);
3968 }
3969#endif
3970 d->updateGeometry_helper(forceUpdate: d->extra->minw == d->extra->maxw && d->extra->minh == d->extra->maxh);
3971}
3972
3973bool QWidgetPrivate::setMaximumSize_helper(int &maxw, int &maxh)
3974{
3975 Q_Q(QWidget);
3976 if (Q_UNLIKELY(maxw > QWIDGETSIZE_MAX || maxh > QWIDGETSIZE_MAX)) {
3977 qWarning(msg: "QWidget::setMaximumSize: (%s/%s) "
3978 "The largest allowed size is (%d,%d)",
3979 q->objectName().toLocal8Bit().data(), q->metaObject()->className(), QWIDGETSIZE_MAX,
3980 QWIDGETSIZE_MAX);
3981 maxw = qMin<int>(a: maxw, QWIDGETSIZE_MAX);
3982 maxh = qMin<int>(a: maxh, QWIDGETSIZE_MAX);
3983 }
3984 if (Q_UNLIKELY(maxw < 0 || maxh < 0)) {
3985 qWarning(msg: "QWidget::setMaximumSize: (%s/%s) Negative sizes (%d,%d) "
3986 "are not possible",
3987 q->objectName().toLocal8Bit().data(), q->metaObject()->className(), maxw, maxh);
3988 maxw = qMax(a: maxw, b: 0);
3989 maxh = qMax(a: maxh, b: 0);
3990 }
3991 createExtra();
3992 if (extra->maxw == maxw && extra->maxh == maxh)
3993 return false;
3994 extra->maxw = maxw;
3995 extra->maxh = maxh;
3996 extra->explicitMaxSize = (maxw != QWIDGETSIZE_MAX ? Qt::Horizontal : 0) |
3997 (maxh != QWIDGETSIZE_MAX ? Qt::Vertical : 0);
3998 return true;
3999}
4000
4001/*!
4002 \overload
4003
4004 This function corresponds to setMaximumSize(QSize(\a maxw, \a
4005 maxh)). Sets the maximum width to \a maxw and the maximum height
4006 to \a maxh.
4007*/
4008void QWidget::setMaximumSize(int maxw, int maxh)
4009{
4010 Q_D(QWidget);
4011 if (!d->setMaximumSize_helper(maxw, maxh))
4012 return;
4013
4014 if (isWindow())
4015 d->setConstraints_sys();
4016 if (maxw < width() || maxh < height()) {
4017 bool resized = testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_Resized);
4018 resize(w: qMin(a: maxw,b: width()), h: qMin(a: maxh,b: height()));
4019 setAttribute(Qt::WA_Resized, on: resized); //not a user resize
4020 }
4021
4022#if QT_CONFIG(graphicsview)
4023 if (d->extra) {
4024 if (d->extra->proxyWidget)
4025 d->extra->proxyWidget->setMaximumSize(aw: maxw, ah: maxh);
4026 }
4027#endif
4028
4029 d->updateGeometry_helper(forceUpdate: d->extra->minw == d->extra->maxw && d->extra->minh == d->extra->maxh);
4030}
4031
4032/*!
4033 \overload
4034
4035 Sets the x (width) size increment to \a w and the y (height) size
4036 increment to \a h.
4037*/
4038void QWidget::setSizeIncrement(int w, int h)
4039{
4040 Q_D(QWidget);
4041 d->createTLExtra();
4042 QTLWExtra* x = d->topData();
4043 if (x->incw == w && x->inch == h)
4044 return;
4045 x->incw = w;
4046 x->inch = h;
4047 if (isWindow())
4048 d->setConstraints_sys();
4049}
4050
4051/*!
4052 \overload
4053
4054 This corresponds to setBaseSize(QSize(\a basew, \a baseh)). Sets
4055 the widgets base size to width \a basew and height \a baseh.
4056*/
4057void QWidget::setBaseSize(int basew, int baseh)
4058{
4059 Q_D(QWidget);
4060 d->createTLExtra();
4061 QTLWExtra* x = d->topData();
4062 if (x->basew == basew && x->baseh == baseh)
4063 return;
4064 x->basew = basew;
4065 x->baseh = baseh;
4066 if (isWindow())
4067 d->setConstraints_sys();
4068}
4069
4070/*!
4071 Sets both the minimum and maximum sizes of the widget to \a s,
4072 thereby preventing it from ever growing or shrinking.
4073
4074 This will override the default size constraints set by QLayout.
4075
4076 To remove constraints, set the size to QWIDGETSIZE_MAX.
4077
4078 Alternatively, if you want the widget to have a
4079 fixed size based on its contents, you can call
4080 QLayout::setSizeConstraint(QLayout::SetFixedSize);
4081
4082 \sa maximumSize, minimumSize
4083*/
4084
4085void QWidget::setFixedSize(const QSize & s)
4086{
4087 setFixedSize(w: s.width(), h: s.height());
4088}
4089
4090
4091/*!
4092 \fn void QWidget::setFixedSize(int w, int h)
4093 \overload
4094
4095 Sets the width of the widget to \a w and the height to \a h.
4096*/
4097
4098void QWidget::setFixedSize(int w, int h)
4099{
4100 Q_D(QWidget);
4101 bool minSizeSet = d->setMinimumSize_helper(minw&: w, minh&: h);
4102 bool maxSizeSet = d->setMaximumSize_helper(maxw&: w, maxh&: h);
4103 if (!minSizeSet && !maxSizeSet)
4104 return;
4105
4106 if (isWindow())
4107 d->setConstraints_sys();
4108 else
4109 d->updateGeometry_helper(forceUpdate: true);
4110
4111 if (w != QWIDGETSIZE_MAX || h != QWIDGETSIZE_MAX)
4112 resize(w, h);
4113}
4114
4115void QWidget::setMinimumWidth(int w)
4116{
4117 Q_D(QWidget);
4118 d->createExtra();
4119 uint expl = d->extra->explicitMinSize | (w ? Qt::Horizontal : 0);
4120 setMinimumSize(minw: w, minh: minimumSize().height());
4121 d->extra->explicitMinSize = expl;
4122}
4123
4124void QWidget::setMinimumHeight(int h)
4125{
4126 Q_D(QWidget);
4127 d->createExtra();
4128 uint expl = d->extra->explicitMinSize | (h ? Qt::Vertical : 0);
4129 setMinimumSize(minw: minimumSize().width(), minh: h);
4130 d->extra->explicitMinSize = expl;
4131}
4132
4133void QWidget::setMaximumWidth(int w)
4134{
4135 Q_D(QWidget);
4136 d->createExtra();
4137 uint expl = d->extra->explicitMaxSize | (w == QWIDGETSIZE_MAX ? 0 : Qt::Horizontal);
4138 setMaximumSize(maxw: w, maxh: maximumSize().height());
4139 d->extra->explicitMaxSize = expl;
4140}
4141
4142void QWidget::setMaximumHeight(int h)
4143{
4144 Q_D(QWidget);
4145 d->createExtra();
4146 uint expl = d->extra->explicitMaxSize | (h == QWIDGETSIZE_MAX ? 0 : Qt::Vertical);
4147 setMaximumSize(maxw: maximumSize().width(), maxh: h);
4148 d->extra->explicitMaxSize = expl;
4149}
4150
4151/*!
4152 Sets both the minimum and maximum width of the widget to \a w
4153 without changing the heights. Provided for convenience.
4154
4155 \sa sizeHint(), minimumSize(), maximumSize(), setFixedSize()
4156*/
4157
4158void QWidget::setFixedWidth(int w)
4159{
4160 Q_D(QWidget);
4161 d->createExtra();
4162 uint explMin = d->extra->explicitMinSize | Qt::Horizontal;
4163 uint explMax = d->extra->explicitMaxSize | Qt::Horizontal;
4164 setMinimumSize(minw: w, minh: minimumSize().height());
4165 setMaximumSize(maxw: w, maxh: maximumSize().height());
4166 d->extra->explicitMinSize = explMin;
4167 d->extra->explicitMaxSize = explMax;
4168}
4169
4170
4171/*!
4172 Sets both the minimum and maximum heights of the widget to \a h
4173 without changing the widths. Provided for convenience.
4174
4175 \sa sizeHint(), minimumSize(), maximumSize(), setFixedSize()
4176*/
4177
4178void QWidget::setFixedHeight(int h)
4179{
4180 Q_D(QWidget);
4181 d->createExtra();
4182 uint explMin = d->extra->explicitMinSize | Qt::Vertical;
4183 uint explMax = d->extra->explicitMaxSize | Qt::Vertical;
4184 setMinimumSize(minw: minimumSize().width(), minh: h);
4185 setMaximumSize(maxw: maximumSize().width(), maxh: h);
4186 d->extra->explicitMinSize = explMin;
4187 d->extra->explicitMaxSize = explMax;
4188}
4189
4190
4191/*!
4192 Translates the widget coordinate \a pos to the coordinate system
4193 of \a parent. The \a parent must not be \nullptr and must be a parent
4194 of the calling widget.
4195
4196 \sa mapFrom(), mapToParent(), mapToGlobal(), underMouse()
4197 \since 6.0
4198*/
4199
4200QPointF QWidget::mapTo(const QWidget *parent, const QPointF &pos) const
4201{
4202 QPointF p = pos;
4203 if (parent) {
4204 const QWidget * w = this;
4205 while (w != parent) {
4206 Q_ASSERT_X(w, "QWidget::mapTo(const QWidget *parent, const QPointF &pos)",
4207 "parent must be in parent hierarchy");
4208 p = w->mapToParent(p);
4209 w = w->parentWidget();
4210 }
4211 }
4212 return p;
4213}
4214
4215/*!
4216 \overload
4217*/
4218QPoint QWidget::mapTo(const QWidget *parent, const QPoint &pos) const
4219{
4220 return mapTo(parent, pos: QPointF(pos)).toPoint();
4221}
4222
4223/*!
4224 Translates the widget coordinate \a pos from the coordinate system
4225 of \a parent to this widget's coordinate system. The \a parent
4226 must not be \nullptr and must be a parent of the calling widget.
4227
4228 \sa mapTo(), mapFromParent(), mapFromGlobal(), underMouse()
4229 \since 6.0
4230*/
4231
4232QPointF QWidget::mapFrom(const QWidget *parent, const QPointF &pos) const
4233{
4234 QPointF p(pos);
4235 if (parent) {
4236 const QWidget * w = this;
4237 while (w != parent) {
4238 Q_ASSERT_X(w, "QWidget::mapFrom(const QWidget *parent, const QPoint &pos)",
4239 "parent must be in parent hierarchy");
4240
4241 p = w->mapFromParent(p);
4242 w = w->parentWidget();
4243 }
4244 }
4245 return p;
4246}
4247
4248/*!
4249 \overload
4250*/
4251QPoint QWidget::mapFrom(const QWidget *parent, const QPoint &pos) const
4252{
4253 return mapFrom(parent, pos: QPointF(pos)).toPoint();
4254}
4255
4256/*!
4257 Translates the widget coordinate \a pos to a coordinate in the
4258 parent widget.
4259
4260 Same as mapToGlobal() if the widget has no parent.
4261
4262 \sa mapFromParent(), mapTo(), mapToGlobal(), underMouse()
4263 \since 6.0
4264*/
4265
4266QPointF QWidget::mapToParent(const QPointF &pos) const
4267{
4268 return pos + QPointF(data->crect.topLeft());
4269}
4270
4271/*!
4272 \overload
4273*/
4274QPoint QWidget::mapToParent(const QPoint &pos) const
4275{
4276 return pos + data->crect.topLeft();
4277}
4278
4279/*!
4280 Translates the parent widget coordinate \a pos to widget
4281 coordinates.
4282
4283 Same as mapFromGlobal() if the widget has no parent.
4284
4285 \sa mapToParent(), mapFrom(), mapFromGlobal(), underMouse()
4286 \since 6.0
4287*/
4288
4289QPointF QWidget::mapFromParent(const QPointF &pos) const
4290{
4291 return pos - QPointF(data->crect.topLeft());
4292}
4293
4294/*!
4295 \overload
4296*/
4297QPoint QWidget::mapFromParent(const QPoint &pos) const
4298{
4299 return pos - data->crect.topLeft();
4300}
4301
4302
4303/*!
4304 Returns the window for this widget, i.e. the next ancestor widget
4305 that has (or could have) a window-system frame.
4306
4307 If the widget is a window, the widget itself is returned.
4308
4309 Typical usage is changing the window title:
4310
4311 \snippet code/src_gui_kernel_qwidget.cpp 3
4312
4313 \sa isWindow()
4314*/
4315
4316QWidget *QWidget::window() const
4317{
4318 QWidget *w = const_cast<QWidget *>(this);
4319 QWidget *p = w->parentWidget();
4320 while (!w->isWindow() && p) {
4321 w = p;
4322 p = p->parentWidget();
4323 }
4324 return w;
4325}
4326
4327/*!
4328 \since 4.4
4329
4330 Returns the native parent for this widget, i.e. the next ancestor widget
4331 that has a system identifier, or \nullptr if it does not have any native
4332 parent.
4333
4334 \sa effectiveWinId()
4335*/
4336QWidget *QWidget::nativeParentWidget() const
4337{
4338 QWidget *parent = parentWidget();
4339 while (parent && !parent->internalWinId())
4340 parent = parent->parentWidget();
4341 return parent;
4342}
4343
4344/*! \fn QWidget *QWidget::topLevelWidget() const
4345 \deprecated
4346
4347 Use window() instead.
4348*/
4349
4350
4351
4352/*!
4353 Returns the background role of the widget.
4354
4355 The background role defines the brush from the widget's \l palette that
4356 is used to render the background.
4357
4358 If no explicit background role is set, the widget inherts its parent
4359 widget's background role.
4360
4361 \sa setBackgroundRole(), foregroundRole()
4362 */
4363QPalette::ColorRole QWidget::backgroundRole() const
4364{
4365
4366 const QWidget *w = this;
4367 do {
4368 QPalette::ColorRole role = w->d_func()->bg_role;
4369 if (role != QPalette::NoRole)
4370 return role;
4371 if (w->isWindow() || w->windowType() == Qt::SubWindow)
4372 break;
4373 w = w->parentWidget();
4374 } while (w);
4375 return QPalette::Window;
4376}
4377
4378/*!
4379 Sets the background role of the widget to \a role.
4380
4381 The background role defines the brush from the widget's \l palette that
4382 is used to render the background.
4383
4384 If \a role is QPalette::NoRole, then the widget inherits its
4385 parent's background role.
4386
4387 Note that styles are free to choose any color from the palette.
4388 You can modify the palette or set a style sheet if you don't
4389 achieve the result you want with setBackgroundRole().
4390
4391 \sa backgroundRole(), foregroundRole()
4392 */
4393
4394void QWidget::setBackgroundRole(QPalette::ColorRole role)
4395{
4396 Q_D(QWidget);
4397 d->bg_role = role;
4398 d->updateSystemBackground();
4399 d->propagatePaletteChange();
4400 d->updateIsOpaque();
4401}
4402
4403/*!
4404 Returns the foreground role.
4405
4406 The foreground role defines the color from the widget's \l palette that
4407 is used to draw the foreground.
4408
4409 If no explicit foreground role is set, the function returns a role
4410 that contrasts with the background role.
4411
4412 \sa setForegroundRole(), backgroundRole()
4413 */
4414QPalette::ColorRole QWidget::foregroundRole() const
4415{
4416 Q_D(const QWidget);
4417 QPalette::ColorRole rl = QPalette::ColorRole(d->fg_role);
4418 if (rl != QPalette::NoRole)
4419 return rl;
4420 QPalette::ColorRole role = QPalette::WindowText;
4421 switch (backgroundRole()) {
4422 case QPalette::Button:
4423 role = QPalette::ButtonText;
4424 break;
4425 case QPalette::Base:
4426 role = QPalette::Text;
4427 break;
4428 case QPalette::Dark:
4429 case QPalette::Shadow:
4430 role = QPalette::Light;
4431 break;
4432 case QPalette::Highlight:
4433 role = QPalette::HighlightedText;
4434 break;
4435 case QPalette::ToolTipBase:
4436 role = QPalette::ToolTipText;
4437 break;
4438 default:
4439 ;
4440 }
4441 return role;
4442}
4443
4444/*!
4445 Sets the foreground role of the widget to \a role.
4446
4447 The foreground role defines the color from the widget's \l palette that
4448 is used to draw the foreground.
4449
4450 If \a role is QPalette::NoRole, the widget uses a foreground role
4451 that contrasts with the background role.
4452
4453 Note that styles are free to choose any color from the palette.
4454 You can modify the palette or set a style sheet if you don't
4455 achieve the result you want with setForegroundRole().
4456
4457 \sa foregroundRole(), backgroundRole()
4458 */
4459void QWidget::setForegroundRole(QPalette::ColorRole role)
4460{
4461 Q_D(QWidget);
4462 d->fg_role = role;
4463 d->updateSystemBackground();
4464 d->propagatePaletteChange();
4465}
4466
4467/*!
4468 \property QWidget::palette
4469 \brief the widget's palette
4470
4471 This property describes the widget's palette. The palette is used by the
4472 widget's style when rendering standard components, and is available as a
4473 means to ensure that custom widgets can maintain consistency with the
4474 native platform's look and feel. It's common that different platforms, or
4475 different styles, have different palettes.
4476
4477 When you assign a new palette to a widget, the color roles from this
4478 palette are combined with the widget's default palette to form the
4479 widget's final palette. The palette entry for the widget's background role
4480 is used to fill the widget's background (see QWidget::autoFillBackground),
4481 and the foreground role initializes QPainter's pen.
4482
4483 The default depends on the system environment. QApplication maintains a
4484 system/theme palette which serves as a default for all widgets. There may
4485 also be special palette defaults for certain types of widgets (e.g., on
4486 Windows Vista, all classes that derive from QMenuBar have a special
4487 default palette). You can also define default palettes for widgets
4488 yourself by passing a custom palette and the name of a widget to
4489 QApplication::setPalette(). Finally, the style always has the option of
4490 polishing the palette as it's assigned (see QStyle::polish()).
4491
4492 QWidget propagates explicit palette roles from parent to child. If you
4493 assign a brush or color to a specific role on a palette and assign that
4494 palette to a widget, that role will propagate to all the widget's
4495 children, overriding any system defaults for that role. Note that palettes
4496 by default don't propagate to windows (see isWindow()) unless the
4497 Qt::WA_WindowPropagation attribute is enabled.
4498
4499 QWidget's palette propagation is similar to its font propagation.
4500
4501 The current style, which is used to render the content of all standard Qt
4502 widgets, is free to choose colors and brushes from the widget palette, or
4503 in some cases, to ignore the palette (partially, or completely). In
4504 particular, certain styles like GTK style, Mac style, and Windows Vista
4505 style, depend on third party APIs to render the content of widgets,
4506 and these styles typically do not follow the palette. Because of this,
4507 assigning roles to a widget's palette is not guaranteed to change the
4508 appearance of the widget. Instead, you may choose to apply a \l {styleSheet}.
4509
4510 \warning Do not use this function in conjunction with \l{Qt Style Sheets}.
4511 When using style sheets, the palette of a widget can be customized using
4512 the "color", "background-color", "selection-color",
4513 "selection-background-color" and "alternate-background-color".
4514
4515 \sa QGuiApplication::palette(), QWidget::font(), {Qt Style Sheets}
4516*/
4517const QPalette &QWidget::palette() const
4518{
4519 if (!isEnabled()) {
4520 data->pal.setCurrentColorGroup(QPalette::Disabled);
4521 } else if ((!isVisible() || isActiveWindow())
4522#if defined(Q_OS_WIN)
4523 && !QApplicationPrivate::isBlockedByModal(const_cast<QWidget *>(this))
4524#endif
4525 ) {
4526 data->pal.setCurrentColorGroup(QPalette::Active);
4527 } else {
4528 data->pal.setCurrentColorGroup(QPalette::Inactive);
4529 }
4530 return data->pal;
4531}
4532
4533void QWidget::setPalette(const QPalette &palette)
4534{
4535 Q_D(QWidget);
4536 setAttribute(Qt::WA_SetPalette, on: palette.resolveMask() != 0);
4537
4538 // Determine which palette is inherited from this widget's ancestors and
4539 // QApplication::palette, resolve this against \a palette (attributes from
4540 // the inherited palette are copied over this widget's palette). Then
4541 // propagate this palette to this widget's children.
4542 QPalette naturalPalette = d->naturalWidgetPalette(inheritedMask: d->inheritedPaletteResolveMask);
4543 QPalette resolvedPalette = palette.resolve(other: naturalPalette);
4544 d->setPalette_helper(resolvedPalette);
4545}
4546
4547/*!
4548 \internal
4549
4550 Returns the palette that the widget \a w inherits from its ancestors and
4551 QApplication::palette. \a inheritedMask is the combination of the widget's
4552 ancestors palette request masks (i.e., which attributes from the parent
4553 widget's palette are implicitly imposed on this widget by the user). Note
4554 that this font does not take into account the palette set on \a w itself.
4555*/
4556QPalette QWidgetPrivate::naturalWidgetPalette(QPalette::ResolveMask inheritedMask) const
4557{
4558 Q_Q(const QWidget);
4559
4560 const bool useStyleSheetPropagationInWidgetStyles =
4561 QCoreApplication::testAttribute(attribute: Qt::AA_UseStyleSheetPropagationInWidgetStyles);
4562
4563 QPalette naturalPalette = QApplication::palette(q);
4564 if ((!q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_StyleSheet) || useStyleSheetPropagationInWidgetStyles)
4565 && (!q->isWindow() || q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WindowPropagation)
4566#if QT_CONFIG(graphicsview)
4567 || (extra && extra->proxyWidget)
4568#endif // QT_CONFIG(graphicsview)
4569 )) {
4570 if (QWidget *p = q->parentWidget()) {
4571 if (!p->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_StyleSheet) || useStyleSheetPropagationInWidgetStyles) {
4572 if (!naturalPalette.isCopyOf(p: QGuiApplication::palette())) {
4573 QPalette inheritedPalette = p->palette();
4574 inheritedPalette.setResolveMask(inheritedMask);
4575 naturalPalette = inheritedPalette.resolve(other: naturalPalette);
4576 } else {
4577 naturalPalette = p->palette();
4578 }
4579 }
4580 }
4581#if QT_CONFIG(graphicsview)
4582 else if (extra && extra->proxyWidget) {
4583 QPalette inheritedPalette = extra->proxyWidget->palette();
4584 inheritedPalette.setResolveMask(inheritedMask);
4585 naturalPalette = inheritedPalette.resolve(other: naturalPalette);
4586 }
4587#endif // QT_CONFIG(graphicsview)
4588 }
4589 naturalPalette.setResolveMask(0);
4590 return naturalPalette;
4591}
4592/*!
4593 \internal
4594
4595 Determine which palette is inherited from this widget's ancestors and
4596 QApplication::palette, resolve this against this widget's palette
4597 (attributes from the inherited palette are copied over this widget's
4598 palette). Then propagate this palette to this widget's children.
4599*/
4600void QWidgetPrivate::resolvePalette()
4601{
4602 QPalette naturalPalette = naturalWidgetPalette(inheritedMask: inheritedPaletteResolveMask);
4603 QPalette resolvedPalette = data.pal.resolve(other: naturalPalette);
4604 setPalette_helper(resolvedPalette);
4605}
4606
4607void QWidgetPrivate::setPalette_helper(const QPalette &palette)
4608{
4609 Q_Q(QWidget);
4610 if (data.pal == palette && data.pal.resolveMask() == palette.resolveMask())
4611 return;
4612 data.pal = palette;
4613 updateSystemBackground();
4614 propagatePaletteChange();
4615 updateIsOpaque();
4616 q->update();
4617 updateIsOpaque();
4618}
4619
4620void QWidgetPrivate::updateSystemBackground()
4621{
4622}
4623
4624/*!
4625 \property QWidget::font
4626 \brief the font currently set for the widget
4627
4628 This property describes the widget's requested font. The font is used by
4629 the widget's style when rendering standard components, and is available as
4630 a means to ensure that custom widgets can maintain consistency with the
4631 native platform's look and feel. It's common that different platforms, or
4632 different styles, define different fonts for an application.
4633
4634 When you assign a new font to a widget, the properties from this font are
4635 combined with the widget's default font to form the widget's final
4636 font. You can call fontInfo() to get a copy of the widget's final
4637 font. The final font is also used to initialize QPainter's font.
4638
4639 The default depends on the system environment. QApplication maintains a
4640 system/theme font which serves as a default for all widgets. There may
4641 also be special font defaults for certain types of widgets. You can also
4642 define default fonts for widgets yourself by passing a custom font and the
4643 name of a widget to QApplication::setFont(). Finally, the font is matched
4644 against Qt's font database to find the best match.
4645
4646 QWidget propagates explicit font properties from parent to child. If you
4647 change a specific property on a font and assign that font to a widget,
4648 that property will propagate to all the widget's children, overriding any
4649 system defaults for that property. Note that fonts by default don't
4650 propagate to windows (see isWindow()) unless the Qt::WA_WindowPropagation
4651 attribute is enabled.
4652
4653 QWidget's font propagation is similar to its palette propagation.
4654
4655 The current style, which is used to render the content of all standard Qt
4656 widgets, is free to choose to use the widget font, or in some cases, to
4657 ignore it (partially, or completely). In particular, certain styles like
4658 GTK style, Mac style, and Windows Vista style, apply special
4659 modifications to the widget font to match the platform's native look and
4660 feel. Because of this, assigning properties to a widget's font is not
4661 guaranteed to change the appearance of the widget. Instead, you may choose
4662 to apply a \l styleSheet.
4663
4664 \note If \l{Qt Style Sheets} are used on the same widget as setFont(),
4665 style sheets will take precedence if the settings conflict.
4666
4667 \sa fontInfo(), fontMetrics()
4668*/
4669
4670void QWidget::setFont(const QFont &font)
4671{
4672 Q_D(QWidget);
4673
4674#ifndef QT_NO_STYLE_STYLESHEET
4675 const QStyleSheetStyle* style;
4676 if (d->extra && (style = qt_styleSheet(style: d->extra->style)))
4677 style->saveWidgetFont(w: this, font);
4678#endif
4679
4680 setAttribute(Qt::WA_SetFont, on: font.resolveMask() != 0);
4681
4682 // Determine which font is inherited from this widget's ancestors and
4683 // QApplication::font, resolve this against \a font (attributes from the
4684 // inherited font are copied over). Then propagate this font to this
4685 // widget's children.
4686 QFont naturalFont = d->naturalWidgetFont(inheritedMask: d->inheritedFontResolveMask);
4687 QFont resolvedFont = font.resolve(naturalFont);
4688 d->setFont_helper(resolvedFont);
4689}
4690
4691/*
4692 \internal
4693
4694 Returns the font that the widget \a w inherits from its ancestors and
4695 QApplication::font. \a inheritedMask is the combination of the widget's
4696 ancestors font request masks (i.e., which attributes from the parent
4697 widget's font are implicitly imposed on this widget by the user). Note
4698 that this font does not take into account the font set on \a w itself.
4699
4700 ### Stylesheet has a different font propagation mechanism. When a stylesheet
4701 is applied, fonts are not propagated anymore
4702*/
4703QFont QWidgetPrivate::naturalWidgetFont(uint inheritedMask) const
4704{
4705 Q_Q(const QWidget);
4706
4707 const bool useStyleSheetPropagationInWidgetStyles =
4708 QCoreApplication::testAttribute(attribute: Qt::AA_UseStyleSheetPropagationInWidgetStyles);
4709
4710 QFont naturalFont = QApplication::font(q);
4711 if ((!q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_StyleSheet) || useStyleSheetPropagationInWidgetStyles)
4712 && (!q->isWindow() || q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WindowPropagation)
4713#if QT_CONFIG(graphicsview)
4714 || (extra && extra->proxyWidget)
4715#endif // QT_CONFIG(graphicsview)
4716 )) {
4717 if (QWidget *p = q->parentWidget()) {
4718 if (!p->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_StyleSheet) || useStyleSheetPropagationInWidgetStyles) {
4719 if (!naturalFont.isCopyOf(QApplication::font())) {
4720 if (inheritedMask != 0) {
4721 QFont inheritedFont = p->font();
4722 inheritedFont.setResolveMask(inheritedMask);
4723 naturalFont = inheritedFont.resolve(naturalFont);
4724 } // else nothing to do (naturalFont = naturalFont)
4725 } else {
4726 naturalFont = p->font();
4727 }
4728 }
4729 }
4730#if QT_CONFIG(graphicsview)
4731 else if (extra && extra->proxyWidget) {
4732 if (inheritedMask != 0) {
4733 QFont inheritedFont = extra->proxyWidget->font();
4734 inheritedFont.setResolveMask(inheritedMask);
4735 naturalFont = inheritedFont.resolve(naturalFont);
4736 } // else nothing to do (naturalFont = naturalFont)
4737 }
4738#endif // QT_CONFIG(graphicsview)
4739 }
4740 naturalFont.setResolveMask(0);
4741 return naturalFont;
4742}
4743
4744/*!
4745 \internal
4746
4747 Returns a font suitable for inheritance, where only locally set attributes are considered resolved.
4748*/
4749QFont QWidgetPrivate::localFont() const
4750{
4751 QFont localfont = data.fnt;
4752 localfont.setResolveMask(directFontResolveMask);
4753 return localfont;
4754}
4755
4756/*!
4757 \internal
4758
4759 Determine which font is implicitly imposed on this widget by its ancestors
4760 and QApplication::font, resolve this against its own font (attributes from
4761 the implicit font are copied over). Then propagate this font to this
4762 widget's children.
4763*/
4764void QWidgetPrivate::resolveFont()
4765{
4766 QFont naturalFont = naturalWidgetFont(inheritedMask: inheritedFontResolveMask);
4767 QFont resolvedFont = localFont().resolve(naturalFont);
4768 setFont_helper(resolvedFont);
4769}
4770
4771/*!
4772 \internal
4773
4774 Assign \a font to this widget, and propagate it to all children, except
