9453 mouseReleaseEvent() may not end up where you expect, depending on
9454 the underlying window system (or X11 window manager), the widgets'
9455 location and maybe more.
9456
9457 The default implementation implements the closing of popup widgets
9458 when you click outside the window. For other widget types it does
9459 nothing.
9460
9461 \sa mouseReleaseEvent(), mouseDoubleClickEvent(),
9462 mouseMoveEvent(), event(), QMouseEvent, {Scribble Example}
9463*/
9464
9465void QWidget::mousePressEvent(QMouseEvent *event)
9466{
9467 event->ignore();
9468 if ((windowType() == Qt::Popup)) {
9469 event->accept();
9470 QWidget* w;
9471 while ((w = QApplication::activePopupWidget()) && w != this){
9472 w->close();
9473 if (QApplication::activePopupWidget() == w) // widget does not want to disappear
9474 w->hide(); // hide at least
9475 }
9476 if (!rect().contains(p: event->position().toPoint())){
9477 close();
9478 }
9479 }
9480}
9481
9482/*!
9483 This event handler, for event \a event, can be reimplemented in a
9484 subclass to receive mouse release events for the widget.
9485
9486 \sa mousePressEvent(), mouseDoubleClickEvent(),
9487 mouseMoveEvent(), event(), QMouseEvent, {Scribble Example}
9488*/
9489
9490void QWidget::mouseReleaseEvent(QMouseEvent *event)
9491{
9492 event->ignore();
9493}
9494
9495/*!
9496 This event handler, for event \a event, can be reimplemented in a
9497 subclass to receive mouse double click events for the widget.
9498
9499 The default implementation calls mousePressEvent().
9500
9501 \note The widget will also receive mouse press and mouse release
9502 events in addition to the double click event. And if another widget
9503 that overlaps this widget disappears in response to press or
9504 release events, then this widget will only receive the double click
9505 event. It is up to the developer to ensure that the application
9506 interprets these events correctly.
9507
9508 \sa mousePressEvent(), mouseReleaseEvent(), mouseMoveEvent(),
9509 event(), QMouseEvent
9510*/
9511
9512void QWidget::mouseDoubleClickEvent(QMouseEvent *event)
9513{
9514 mousePressEvent(event);
9515}
9516
9517#if QT_CONFIG(wheelevent)
9518/*!
9519 This event handler, for event \a event, can be reimplemented in a
9520 subclass to receive wheel events for the widget.
9521
9522 If you reimplement this handler, it is very important that you
9523 \l{QEvent}{ignore()} the event if you do not handle
9524 it, so that the widget's parent can interpret it.
9525
9526 The default implementation ignores the event.
9527
9528 \sa QEvent::ignore(), QEvent::accept(), event(),
9529 QWheelEvent
9530*/
9531
9532void QWidget::wheelEvent(QWheelEvent *event)
9533{
9534 event->ignore();
9535}
9536#endif // QT_CONFIG(wheelevent)
9537
9538#if QT_CONFIG(tabletevent)
9539/*!
9540 This event handler, for event \a event, can be reimplemented in a
9541 subclass to receive tablet events for the widget.
9542
9543 If you reimplement this handler, it is very important that you
9544 \l{QEvent}{ignore()} the event if you do not handle
9545 it, so that the widget's parent can interpret it.
9546
9547 The default implementation ignores the event.
9548
9549 If tablet tracking is switched off, tablet move events only occur if the
9550 stylus is in contact with the tablet, or at least one stylus button is
9551 pressed, while the stylus is being moved. If tablet tracking is switched on,
9552 tablet move events occur even while the stylus is hovering in proximity of
9553 the tablet, with no buttons pressed.
9554
9555 \sa QEvent::ignore(), QEvent::accept(), event(), setTabletTracking(),
9556 QTabletEvent
9557*/
9558
9559void QWidget::tabletEvent(QTabletEvent *event)
9560{
9561 event->ignore();
9562}
9563#endif // QT_CONFIG(tabletevent)
9564
9565/*!
9566 This event handler, for event \a event, can be reimplemented in a
9567 subclass to receive key press events for the widget.
9568
9569 A widget must call setFocusPolicy() to accept focus initially and
9570 have focus in order to receive a key press event.
9571
9572 If you reimplement this handler, it is very important that you
9573 call the base class implementation if you do not act upon the key.
9574
9575 The default implementation closes popup widgets if the user
9576 presses the key sequence for QKeySequence::Cancel (typically the
9577 Escape key). Otherwise the event is ignored, so that the widget's
9578 parent can interpret it.
9579
9580 Note that QKeyEvent starts with isAccepted() == true, so you do not
9581 need to call QKeyEvent::accept() - just do not call the base class
9582 implementation if you act upon the key.
9583
9584 \sa keyReleaseEvent(), setFocusPolicy(),
9585 focusInEvent(), focusOutEvent(), event(), QKeyEvent, {Tetrix Example}
9586*/
9587
9588void QWidget::keyPressEvent(QKeyEvent *event)
9589{
9590#ifndef QT_NO_SHORTCUT
9591 if ((windowType() == Qt::Popup) && event->matches(key: QKeySequence::Cancel)) {
9592 event->accept();
9593 close();
9594 } else
9595#endif
9596 {
9597 event->ignore();
9598 }
9599}
9600
9601/*!
9602 This event handler, for event \a event, can be reimplemented in a
9603 subclass to receive key release events for the widget.
9604
9605 A widget must \l{setFocusPolicy()}{accept focus}
9606 initially and \l{hasFocus()}{have focus} in order to
9607 receive a key release event.
9608
9609 If you reimplement this handler, it is very important that you
9610 call the base class implementation if you do not act upon the key.
9611
9612 The default implementation ignores the event, so that the widget's
9613 parent can interpret it.
9614
9615 Note that QKeyEvent starts with isAccepted() == true, so you do not
9616 need to call QKeyEvent::accept() - just do not call the base class
9617 implementation if you act upon the key.
9618
9619 \sa keyPressEvent(), QEvent::ignore(), setFocusPolicy(),
9620 focusInEvent(), focusOutEvent(), event(), QKeyEvent
9621*/
9622
9623void QWidget::keyReleaseEvent(QKeyEvent *event)
9624{
9625 event->ignore();
9626}
9627
9628/*!
9629 \fn void QWidget::focusInEvent(QFocusEvent *event)
9630
9631 This event handler can be reimplemented in a subclass to receive
9632 keyboard focus events (focus received) for the widget. The event
9633 is passed in the \a event parameter
9634
9635 A widget normally must setFocusPolicy() to something other than
9636 Qt::NoFocus in order to receive focus events. (Note that the
9637 application programmer can call setFocus() on any widget, even
9638 those that do not normally accept focus.)
9639
9640 The default implementation updates the widget (except for windows
9641 that do not specify a focusPolicy()).
9642
9643 \sa focusOutEvent(), setFocusPolicy(), keyPressEvent(),
9644 keyReleaseEvent(), event(), QFocusEvent
9645*/
9646
9647void QWidget::focusInEvent(QFocusEvent *)
9648{
9649 if (focusPolicy() != Qt::NoFocus || !isWindow()) {
9650 update();
9651 }
9652}
9653
9654/*!
9655 \fn void QWidget::focusOutEvent(QFocusEvent *event)
9656
9657 This event handler can be reimplemented in a subclass to receive
9658 keyboard focus events (focus lost) for the widget. The events is
9659 passed in the \a event parameter.
9660
9661 A widget normally must setFocusPolicy() to something other than
9662 Qt::NoFocus in order to receive focus events. (Note that the
9663 application programmer can call setFocus() on any widget, even
9664 those that do not normally accept focus.)
9665
9666 The default implementation updates the widget (except for windows
9667 that do not specify a focusPolicy()).
9668
9669 \sa focusInEvent(), setFocusPolicy(), keyPressEvent(),
9670 keyReleaseEvent(), event(), QFocusEvent
9671*/
9672
9673void QWidget::focusOutEvent(QFocusEvent *)
9674{
9675 if (focusPolicy() != Qt::NoFocus || !isWindow())
9676 update();
9677
9678#if !defined(QT_PLATFORM_UIKIT)
9679 // FIXME: revisit autoSIP logic, QTBUG-42906
9680 if (qApp->autoSipEnabled() && testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_InputMethodEnabled))
9681 QGuiApplication::inputMethod()->hide();
9682#endif
9683}
9684
9685/*!
9686 \fn void QWidget::enterEvent(QEnterEvent *event)
9687
9688 This event handler can be reimplemented in a subclass to receive
9689 widget enter events which are passed in the \a event parameter.
9690
9691 An event is sent to the widget when the mouse cursor enters the
9692 widget.
9693
9694 \sa leaveEvent(), mouseMoveEvent(), event()
9695*/
9696
9697void QWidget::enterEvent(QEnterEvent *)
9698{
9699}
9700
9701/*!
9702 \fn void QWidget::leaveEvent(QEvent *event)
9703
9704 This event handler can be reimplemented in a subclass to receive
9705 widget leave events which are passed in the \a event parameter.
9706
9707 A leave event is sent to the widget when the mouse cursor leaves
9708 the widget.
9709
9710 \sa enterEvent(), mouseMoveEvent(), event()
9711*/
9712
9713void QWidget::leaveEvent(QEvent *)
9714{
9715}
9716
9717/*!
9718 \fn void QWidget::paintEvent(QPaintEvent *event)
9719
9720 This event handler can be reimplemented in a subclass to receive paint
9721 events passed in \a event.
9722
9723 A paint event is a request to repaint all or part of a widget. It can
9724 happen for one of the following reasons:
9725
9726 \list
9727 \li repaint() or update() was invoked,
9728 \li the widget was obscured and has now been uncovered, or
9729 \li many other reasons.
9730 \endlist
9731
9732 Many widgets can simply repaint their entire surface when asked to, but
9733 some slow widgets need to optimize by painting only the requested region:
9734 QPaintEvent::region(). This speed optimization does not change the result,
9735 as painting is clipped to that region during event processing. QListView
9736 and QTableView do this, for example.
9737
9738 Qt also tries to speed up painting by merging multiple paint events into
9739 one. When update() is called several times or the window system sends
9740 several paint events, Qt merges these events into one event with a larger
9741 region (see QRegion::united()). The repaint() function does not permit this
9742 optimization, so we suggest using update() whenever possible.
9743
9744 When the paint event occurs, the update region has normally been erased, so
9745 you are painting on the widget's background.
9746
9747 The background can be set using setBackgroundRole() and setPalette().
9748
9749 Since Qt 4.0, QWidget automatically double-buffers its painting, so there
9750 is no need to write double-buffering code in paintEvent() to avoid flicker.
9751
9752 \note Generally, you should refrain from calling update() or repaint()
9753 \b{inside} a paintEvent(). For example, calling update() or repaint() on
9754 children inside a paintEvent() results in undefined behavior; the child may
9755 or may not get a paint event.
9756
9757 \warning If you are using a custom paint engine without Qt's backingstore,
9758 Qt::WA_PaintOnScreen must be set. Otherwise, QWidget::paintEngine() will
9759 never be called; the backingstore will be used instead.
9760
9761 \sa event(), repaint(), update(), QPainter, QPixmap, QPaintEvent,
9762 {Analog Clock}
9763*/
9764
9765void QWidget::paintEvent(QPaintEvent *)
9766{
9767}
9768
9769
9770/*!
9771 \fn void QWidget::moveEvent(QMoveEvent *event)
9772
9773 This event handler can be reimplemented in a subclass to receive
9774 widget move events which are passed in the \a event parameter.
9775 When the widget receives this event, it is already at the new
9776 position.
9777
9778 The old position is accessible through QMoveEvent::oldPos().
9779
9780 \sa resizeEvent(), event(), move(), QMoveEvent
9781*/
9782
9783void QWidget::moveEvent(QMoveEvent *)
9784{
9785}
9786
9787
9788/*!
9789 This event handler can be reimplemented in a subclass to receive
9790 widget resize events which are passed in the \a event parameter.
9791 When resizeEvent() is called, the widget already has its new
9792 geometry. The old size is accessible through
9793 QResizeEvent::oldSize().
9794
9795 The widget will be erased and receive a paint event immediately
9796 after processing the resize event. No drawing need be (or should
9797 be) done inside this handler.
9798
9799
9800 \sa moveEvent(), event(), resize(), QResizeEvent, paintEvent(),
9801 {Scribble Example}
9802*/
9803
9804void QWidget::resizeEvent(QResizeEvent * /* event */)
9805{
9806}
9807
9808#ifndef QT_NO_ACTION
9809/*!
9810 \fn void QWidget::actionEvent(QActionEvent *event)
9811
9812 This event handler is called with the given \a event whenever the
9813 widget's actions are changed.
9814
9815 \sa addAction(), insertAction(), removeAction(), actions(), QActionEvent
9816*/
9817void QWidget::actionEvent(QActionEvent *)
9818{
9819
9820}
9821#endif
9822
9823/*!
9824 This event handler is called with the given \a event when Qt receives a window
9825 close request for a top-level widget from the window system.
9826
9827 By default, the event is accepted and the widget is closed. You can reimplement
9828 this function to change the way the widget responds to window close requests.
9829 For example, you can prevent the window from closing by calling \l{QEvent::}{ignore()}
9830 on all events.
9831
9832 Main window applications typically use reimplementations of this function to check
9833 whether the user's work has been saved and ask for permission before closing.
9834 For example, the \l{Qt Widgets - Application Example} uses a helper function to
9835 determine whether or not to close the window:
9836
9837 \snippet mainwindows/application/mainwindow.cpp 3
9838 \snippet mainwindows/application/mainwindow.cpp 4
9839
9840 \sa event(), hide(), close(), QCloseEvent, {Qt Widgets - Application Example}
9841*/
9842
9843void QWidget::closeEvent(QCloseEvent *event)
9844{
9845 event->accept();
9846}
9847
9848#ifndef QT_NO_CONTEXTMENU
9849/*!
9850 This event handler, for event \a event, can be reimplemented in a
9851 subclass to receive widget context menu events.
9852
9853 The handler is called when the widget's \l contextMenuPolicy is
9854 Qt::DefaultContextMenu.
9855
9856 The default implementation ignores the context event.
9857 See the \l QContextMenuEvent documentation for more details.
9858
9859 \sa event(), QContextMenuEvent, customContextMenuRequested()
9860*/
9861
9862void QWidget::contextMenuEvent(QContextMenuEvent *event)
9863{
9864 event->ignore();
9865}
9866#endif // QT_NO_CONTEXTMENU
9867
9868
9869/*!
9870 This event handler, for event \a event, can be reimplemented in a
9871 subclass to receive Input Method composition events. This handler
9872 is called when the state of the input method changes.
9873
9874 Note that when creating custom text editing widgets, the
9875 Qt::WA_InputMethodEnabled window attribute must be set explicitly
9876 (using the setAttribute() function) in order to receive input
9877 method events.
9878
9879 The default implementation calls event->ignore(), which rejects the
9880 Input Method event. See the \l QInputMethodEvent documentation for more
9881 details.
9882
9883 \sa event(), QInputMethodEvent
9884*/
9885void QWidget::inputMethodEvent(QInputMethodEvent *event)
9886{
9887 event->ignore();
9888}
9889
9890/*!
9891 This method is only relevant for input widgets. It is used by the
9892 input method to query a set of properties of the widget to be
9893 able to support complex input method operations as support for
9894 surrounding text and reconversions.
9895
9896 \a query specifies which property is queried.
9897
9898 \sa inputMethodEvent(), QInputMethodEvent, QInputMethodQueryEvent, inputMethodHints
9899*/
9900QVariant QWidget::inputMethodQuery(Qt::InputMethodQuery query) const
9901{
9902 switch(query) {
9903 case Qt::ImCursorRectangle:
9904 return QRect(width()/2, 0, 1, height());
9905 case Qt::ImFont:
9906 return font();
9907 case Qt::ImAnchorPosition:
9908 // Fallback.
9909 return inputMethodQuery(query: Qt::ImCursorPosition);
9910 case Qt::ImHints:
9911 return (int)inputMethodHints();
9912 case Qt::ImInputItemClipRectangle:
9913 return d_func()->clipRect();
9914 default:
9915 return QVariant();
9916 }
9917}
9918
9919/*!
9920 \property QWidget::inputMethodHints
9921 \brief What input method specific hints the widget has.
9922
9923 This is only relevant for input widgets. It is used by
9924 the input method to retrieve hints as to how the input method
9925 should operate. For example, if the Qt::ImhFormattedNumbersOnly flag
9926 is set, the input method may change its visual components to reflect
9927 that only numbers can be entered.
9928
9929 \warning Some widgets require certain flags in order to work as
9930 intended. To set a flag, do \c{w->setInputMethodHints(w->inputMethodHints()|f)}
9931 instead of \c{w->setInputMethodHints(f)}.
9932
9933 \note The flags are only hints, so the particular input method
9934 implementation is free to ignore them. If you want to be
9935 sure that a certain type of characters are entered,
9936 you should also set a QValidator on the widget.
9937
9938 The default value is Qt::ImhNone.
9939
9940 \since 4.6
9941
9942 \sa inputMethodQuery()
9943*/
9944Qt::InputMethodHints QWidget::inputMethodHints() const
9945{
9946#if QT_CONFIG(im)
9947 const QWidgetPrivate *priv = d_func();
9948 while (priv->inheritsInputMethodHints) {
9949 priv = priv->q_func()->parentWidget()->d_func();
9950 Q_ASSERT(priv);
9951 }
9952 return priv->imHints;
9953#else
9954 return Qt::ImhNone;
9955#endif
9956}
9957
9958void QWidget::setInputMethodHints(Qt::InputMethodHints hints)
9959{
9960#ifndef QT_NO_IM
9961 Q_D(QWidget);
9962 if (d->imHints == hints)
9963 return;
9964 d->imHints = hints;
9965 if (this == QGuiApplication::focusObject())
9966 QGuiApplication::inputMethod()->update(queries: Qt::ImHints);
9967#else
9968 Q_UNUSED(hints);
9969#endif //QT_NO_IM
9970}
9971
9972
9973#if QT_CONFIG(draganddrop)
9974
9975/*!
9976 \fn void QWidget::dragEnterEvent(QDragEnterEvent *event)
9977
9978 This event handler is called when a drag is in progress and the
9979 mouse enters this widget. The event is passed in the \a event parameter.
9980
9981 If the event is ignored, the widget won't receive any \l{dragMoveEvent()}{drag
9982 move events}.
9983
9984 See the \l{dnd.html}{Drag-and-drop documentation} for an
9985 overview of how to provide drag-and-drop in your application.
9986
9987 \sa QDrag, QDragEnterEvent
9988*/
9989void QWidget::dragEnterEvent(QDragEnterEvent *)
9990{
9991}
9992
9993/*!
9994 \fn void QWidget::dragMoveEvent(QDragMoveEvent *event)
9995
9996 This event handler is called if a drag is in progress, and when
9997 any of the following conditions occur: the cursor enters this widget,
9998 the cursor moves within this widget, or a modifier key is pressed on
9999 the keyboard while this widget has the focus. The event is passed
10000 in the \a event parameter.
10001
10002 See the \l{dnd.html}{Drag-and-drop documentation} for an
10003 overview of how to provide drag-and-drop in your application.
10004
10005 \sa QDrag, QDragMoveEvent
10006*/
10007void QWidget::dragMoveEvent(QDragMoveEvent *)
10008{
10009}
10010
10011/*!
10012 \fn void QWidget::dragLeaveEvent(QDragLeaveEvent *event)
10013
10014 This event handler is called when a drag is in progress and the
10015 mouse leaves this widget. The event is passed in the \a event
10016 parameter.
10017
10018 See the \l{dnd.html}{Drag-and-drop documentation} for an
10019 overview of how to provide drag-and-drop in your application.
10020
10021 \sa QDrag, QDragLeaveEvent
10022*/
10023void QWidget::dragLeaveEvent(QDragLeaveEvent *)
10024{
10025}
10026
10027/*!
10028 \fn void QWidget::dropEvent(QDropEvent *event)
10029
10030 This event handler is called when the drag is dropped on this
10031 widget. The event is passed in the \a event parameter.
10032
10033 See the \l{dnd.html}{Drag-and-drop documentation} for an
10034 overview of how to provide drag-and-drop in your application.
10035
10036 \sa QDrag, QDropEvent
10037*/
10038void QWidget::dropEvent(QDropEvent *)
10039{
10040}
10041
10042#endif // QT_CONFIG(draganddrop)
10043
10044/*!
10045 \fn void QWidget::showEvent(QShowEvent *event)
10046
10047 This event handler can be reimplemented in a subclass to receive
10048 widget show events which are passed in the \a event parameter.
10049
10050 Non-spontaneous show events are sent to widgets immediately
10051 before they are shown. The spontaneous show events of windows are
10052 delivered afterwards.
10053
10054 Note: A widget receives spontaneous show and hide events when its
10055 mapping status is changed by the window system, e.g. a spontaneous
10056 hide event when the user minimizes the window, and a spontaneous
10057 show event when the window is restored again. After receiving a
10058 spontaneous hide event, a widget is still considered visible in
10059 the sense of isVisible().
10060
10061 \sa visible, event(), QShowEvent
10062*/
10063void QWidget::showEvent(QShowEvent *)
10064{
10065}
10066
10067/*!
10068 \fn void QWidget::hideEvent(QHideEvent *event)
10069
10070 This event handler can be reimplemented in a subclass to receive
10071 widget hide events. The event is passed in the \a event parameter.
10072
10073 Hide events are sent to widgets immediately after they have been
10074 hidden.
10075
10076 Note: A widget receives spontaneous show and hide events when its
10077 mapping status is changed by the window system, e.g. a spontaneous
10078 hide event when the user minimizes the window, and a spontaneous
10079 show event when the window is restored again. After receiving a
10080 spontaneous hide event, a widget is still considered visible in
10081 the sense of isVisible().
10082
10083 \sa visible, event(), QHideEvent
10084*/
10085void QWidget::hideEvent(QHideEvent *)
10086{
10087}
10088
10089/*!
10090 This special event handler can be reimplemented in a subclass to
10091 receive native platform events identified by \a eventType
10092 which are passed in the \a message parameter.
10093
10094 In your reimplementation of this function, if you want to stop the
10095 event being handled by Qt, return true and set \a result. The \a result
10096 parameter has meaning only on Windows. If you return false, this native
10097 event is passed back to Qt, which translates the event into a Qt event
10098 and sends it to the widget.
10099
10100 \note Events are only delivered to this event handler if the widget
10101 has a native window handle.
10102
10103 \note This function superseedes the event filter functions
10104 x11Event(), winEvent() and macEvent() of Qt 4.
10105
10106 \sa QAbstractNativeEventFilter
10107
10108 \table
10109 \header \li Platform \li Event Type Identifier \li Message Type \li Result Type
10110 \row \li Windows \li "windows_generic_MSG" \li MSG * \li LRESULT
10111 \row \li macOS \li "NSEvent" \li NSEvent * \li
10112 \row \li XCB \li "xcb_generic_event_t" \li xcb_generic_event_t * \li
10113 \endtable
10114*/
10115
10116bool QWidget::nativeEvent(const QByteArray &eventType, void *message, qintptr *result)
10117{
10118 Q_UNUSED(eventType);
10119 Q_UNUSED(message);
10120 Q_UNUSED(result);
10121 return false;
10122}
10123
10124/*!
10125 Ensures that the widget and its children have been polished by
10126 QStyle (i.e., have a proper font and palette).
10127
10128 QWidget calls this function after it has been fully constructed
10129 but before it is shown the very first time. You can call this
10130 function if you want to ensure that the widget is polished before
10131 doing an operation, e.g., the correct font size might be needed in
10132 the widget's sizeHint() reimplementation. Note that this function
10133 \e is called from the default implementation of sizeHint().
10134
10135 Polishing is useful for final initialization that must happen after
10136 all constructors (from base classes as well as from subclasses)
10137 have been called.
10138
10139 If you need to change some settings when a widget is polished,
10140 reimplement event() and handle the QEvent::Polish event type.
10141
10142 \b{Note:} The function is declared const so that it can be called from
10143 other const functions (e.g., sizeHint()).
10144
10145 \sa event()
10146*/
10147void QWidget::ensurePolished() const
10148{
10149 Q_D(const QWidget);
10150
10151 const QMetaObject *m = metaObject();
10152 if (m == d->polished)
10153 return;
10154 d->polished = m;
10155
10156 QEvent e(QEvent::Polish);
10157 QCoreApplication::sendEvent(receiver: const_cast<QWidget *>(this), event: &e);
10158
10159 // polish children after 'this'
10160 QList<QObject*> children = d->children;
10161 for (int i = 0; i < children.size(); ++i) {
10162 QObject *o = children.at(i);
10163 if (!o->isWidgetType())
10164 continue;
10165 if (QWidget *w = qobject_cast<QWidget *>(o))
10166 w->ensurePolished();
10167 }
10168
10169 if (d->parent && d->sendChildEvents) {
10170 QChildEvent e(QEvent::ChildPolished, const_cast<QWidget *>(this));
10171 QCoreApplication::sendEvent(receiver: d->parent, event: &e);
10172 }
10173}
10174
10175/*!
10176 Returns the mask currently set on a widget. If no mask is set the
10177 return value will be an empty region.
10178
10179 \sa setMask(), clearMask(), QRegion::isEmpty(), {Shaped Clock Example}
10180*/
10181QRegion QWidget::mask() const
10182{
10183 Q_D(const QWidget);
10184 return d->extra ? d->extra->mask : QRegion();
10185}
10186
10187/*!
10188 Returns the layout manager that is installed on this widget, or \nullptr
10189 if no layout manager is installed.
10190
10191 The layout manager sets the geometry of the widget's children
10192 that have been added to the layout.
10193
10194 \sa setLayout(), sizePolicy(), {Layout Management}
10195*/
10196QLayout *QWidget::layout() const
10197{
10198 return d_func()->layout;
10199}
10200
10201
10202/*!
10203 \fn void QWidget::setLayout(QLayout *layout)
10204
10205 Sets the layout manager for this widget to \a layout.
10206
10207 If there already is a layout manager installed on this widget,
10208 QWidget won't let you install another. You must first delete the
10209 existing layout manager (returned by layout()) before you can
10210 call setLayout() with the new layout.
10211
10212 If \a layout is the layout manager on a different widget, setLayout()
10213 will reparent the layout and make it the layout manager for this widget.
10214
10215 Example:
10216
10217 \snippet layouts/layouts.cpp 24
10218
10219 An alternative to calling this function is to pass this widget to
10220 the layout's constructor.
10221
10222 The QWidget will take ownership of \a layout.
10223
10224 \sa layout(), {Layout Management}
10225*/
10226
10227void QWidget::setLayout(QLayout *l)
10228{
10229 if (Q_UNLIKELY(!l)) {
10230 qWarning(msg: "QWidget::setLayout: Cannot set layout to 0");
10231 return;
10232 }
10233 if (layout()) {
10234 if (Q_UNLIKELY(layout() != l))
10235 qWarning(msg: "QWidget::setLayout: Attempting to set QLayout \"%s\" on %s \"%s\", which already has a"
10236 " layout", l->objectName().toLocal8Bit().data(), metaObject()->className(),
10237 objectName().toLocal8Bit().data());
10238 return;
10239 }
10240
10241 QObject *oldParent = l->parent();
10242 if (oldParent && oldParent != this) {
10243 if (oldParent->isWidgetType()) {
10244 // Steal the layout off a widget parent. Takes effect when
10245 // morphing laid-out container widgets in Designer.
10246 QWidget *oldParentWidget = static_cast<QWidget *>(oldParent);
10247 oldParentWidget->takeLayout();
10248 } else {
10249 qWarning(msg: "QWidget::setLayout: Attempting to set QLayout \"%s\" on %s \"%s\", when the QLayout already has a parent",
10250 l->objectName().toLocal8Bit().data(), metaObject()->className(),
10251 objectName().toLocal8Bit().data());
10252 return;
10253 }
10254 }
10255
10256 Q_D(QWidget);
10257 l->d_func()->topLevel = true;
10258 d->layout = l;
10259 if (oldParent != this) {
10260 l->setParent(this);
10261 l->d_func()->reparentChildWidgets(mw: this);
10262 l->invalidate();
10263 }
10264
10265 if (isWindow() && d->maybeTopData())
10266 d->topData()->sizeAdjusted = false;
10267}
10268
10269/*!
10270 \fn QLayout *QWidget::takeLayout()
10271
10272 Remove the layout from the widget.
10273 \since 4.5
10274*/
10275
10276QLayout *QWidget::takeLayout()
10277{
10278 Q_D(QWidget);
10279 QLayout *l = layout();
10280 if (!l)
10281 return nullptr;
10282 d->layout = nullptr;
10283 l->setParent(nullptr);
10284 return l;
10285}
10286
10287/*!
10288 \property QWidget::sizePolicy
10289 \brief the default layout behavior of the widget
10290
10291 If there is a QLayout that manages this widget's children, the
10292 size policy specified by that layout is used. If there is no such
10293 QLayout, the result of this function is used.
10294
10295 The default policy is Preferred/Preferred, which means that the
10296 widget can be freely resized, but prefers to be the size
10297 sizeHint() returns. Button-like widgets set the size policy to
10298 specify that they may stretch horizontally, but are fixed
10299 vertically. The same applies to lineedit controls (such as
10300 QLineEdit, QSpinBox or an editable QComboBox) and other
10301 horizontally orientated widgets (such as QProgressBar).
10302 QToolButton's are normally square, so they allow growth in both
10303 directions. Widgets that support different directions (such as
10304 QSlider, QScrollBar or QHeader) specify stretching in the
10305 respective direction only. Widgets that can provide scroll bars
10306 (usually subclasses of QScrollArea) tend to specify that they can
10307 use additional space, and that they can make do with less than
10308 sizeHint().
10309
10310 \sa sizeHint(), QLayout, QSizePolicy, updateGeometry()
10311*/
10312QSizePolicy QWidget::sizePolicy() const
10313{
10314 Q_D(const QWidget);
10315 return d->size_policy;
10316}
10317
10318void QWidget::setSizePolicy(QSizePolicy policy)
10319{
10320 Q_D(QWidget);
10321 setAttribute(Qt::WA_WState_OwnSizePolicy);
10322 if (policy == d->size_policy)
10323 return;
10324
10325 if (d->size_policy.retainSizeWhenHidden() != policy.retainSizeWhenHidden())
10326 d->retainSizeWhenHiddenChanged = 1;
10327
10328 d->size_policy = policy;
10329
10330#if QT_CONFIG(graphicsview)
10331 if (const auto &extra = d->extra) {
10332 if (extra->proxyWidget)
10333 extra->proxyWidget->setSizePolicy(policy);
10334 }
10335#endif
10336
10337 updateGeometry();
10338 d->retainSizeWhenHiddenChanged = 0;
10339
10340 if (isWindow() && d->maybeTopData())
10341 d->topData()->sizeAdjusted = false;
10342}
10343
10344/*!
10345 \fn void QWidget::setSizePolicy(QSizePolicy::Policy horizontal, QSizePolicy::Policy vertical)
10346 \overload
10347
10348 Sets the size policy of the widget to \a horizontal and \a
10349 vertical, with standard stretch and no height-for-width.
10350
10351 \sa QSizePolicy::QSizePolicy()
10352*/
10353
10354/*!
10355 Returns the preferred height for this widget, given the width \a w.
10356
10357 If this widget has a layout, the default implementation returns
10358 the layout's preferred height. if there is no layout, the default
10359 implementation returns -1 indicating that the preferred height
10360 does not depend on the width.
10361*/
10362
10363int QWidget::heightForWidth(int w) const
10364{
10365 if (layout() && layout()->hasHeightForWidth())
10366 return layout()->totalHeightForWidth(w);
10367 return -1;
10368}
10369
10370
10371/*!
10372 \since 5.0
10373
10374 Returns \c true if the widget's preferred height depends on its width; otherwise returns \c false.
10375*/
10376bool QWidget::hasHeightForWidth() const
10377{
10378 Q_D(const QWidget);
10379 return d->layout ? d->layout->hasHeightForWidth() : d->size_policy.hasHeightForWidth();
10380}
10381
10382/*!
10383 \fn QWidget *QWidget::childAt(int x, int y) const
10384
10385 Returns the visible child widget at the position (\a{x}, \a{y})
10386 in the widget's coordinate system. If there is no visible child
10387 widget at the specified position, the function returns \nullptr.
10388*/
10389
10390/*!
10391 \overload
10392
10393 Returns the visible child widget at point \a p in the widget's own
10394 coordinate system.
10395*/
10396
10397QWidget *QWidget::childAt(const QPoint &p) const
10398{
10399 return d_func()->childAt_helper(p, false);
10400}
10401
10402QWidget *QWidgetPrivate::childAt_helper(const QPoint &p, bool ignoreChildrenInDestructor) const
10403{
10404 if (children.isEmpty())
10405 return nullptr;
10406
10407 if (!pointInsideRectAndMask(p))
10408 return nullptr;
10409 return childAtRecursiveHelper(p, ignoreChildrenInDestructor);
10410}
10411
10412QWidget *QWidgetPrivate::childAtRecursiveHelper(const QPoint &p, bool ignoreChildrenInDestructor) const
10413{
10414 for (int i = children.size() - 1; i >= 0; --i) {
10415 QWidget *child = qobject_cast<QWidget *>(o: children.at(i));
10416 if (!child || child->isWindow() || child->isHidden() || child->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_TransparentForMouseEvents)
10417 || (ignoreChildrenInDestructor && child->data->in_destructor)) {
10418 continue;
10419 }
10420
10421 // Map the point 'p' from parent coordinates to child coordinates.
10422 QPoint childPoint = p;
10423 childPoint -= child->data->crect.topLeft();
10424
10425 // Check if the point hits the child.
10426 if (!child->d_func()->pointInsideRectAndMask(p: childPoint))
10427 continue;
10428
10429 // Do the same for the child's descendants.
10430 if (QWidget *w = child->d_func()->childAtRecursiveHelper(p: childPoint, ignoreChildrenInDestructor))
10431 return w;
10432
10433 // We have found our target; namely the child at position 'p'.
10434 return child;
10435 }
10436 return nullptr;
10437}
10438
10439void QWidgetPrivate::updateGeometry_helper(bool forceUpdate)
10440{
10441 Q_Q(QWidget);
10442 if (widgetItem)
10443 widgetItem->invalidateSizeCache();
10444 QWidget *parent;
10445 if (forceUpdate || !extra || extra->minw != extra->maxw || extra->minh != extra->maxh) {
10446 const int isHidden = q->isHidden() && !size_policy.retainSizeWhenHidden() && !retainSizeWhenHiddenChanged;
10447
10448 if (!q->isWindow() && !isHidden && (parent = q->parentWidget())) {
10449 if (parent->d_func()->layout)
10450 parent->d_func()->layout->invalidate();
10451 else if (parent->isVisible())
10452 QCoreApplication::postEvent(receiver: parent, event: new QEvent(QEvent::LayoutRequest));
10453 }
10454 }
10455}
10456
10457/*!
10458 Notifies the layout system that this widget has changed and may
10459 need to change geometry.
10460
10461 Call this function if the sizeHint() or sizePolicy() have changed.
10462
10463 For explicitly hidden widgets, updateGeometry() is a no-op. The
10464 layout system will be notified as soon as the widget is shown.
10465*/
10466
10467void QWidget::updateGeometry()
10468{
10469 Q_D(QWidget);
10470 d->updateGeometry_helper(forceUpdate: false);
10471}
10472
10473/*! \property QWidget::windowFlags
10474
10475 Window flags are a combination of a type (e.g. Qt::Dialog) and
10476 zero or more hints to the window system (e.g.
10477 Qt::FramelessWindowHint).
10478
10479 If the widget had type Qt::Widget or Qt::SubWindow and becomes a
10480 window (Qt::Window, Qt::Dialog, etc.), it is put at position (0,
10481 0) on the desktop. If the widget is a window and becomes a
10482 Qt::Widget or Qt::SubWindow, it is put at position (0, 0)
10483 relative to its parent widget.
10484
10485 \note This function calls setParent() when changing the flags for
10486 a window, causing the widget to be hidden. You must call show() to make
10487 the widget visible again..
10488
10489 \sa windowType(), setWindowFlag(), {Window Flags Example}
10490*/
10491void QWidget::setWindowFlags(Qt::WindowFlags flags)
10492{
10493 Q_D(QWidget);
10494 d->setWindowFlags(flags);
10495}
10496
10497/*!
10498 \since 5.9
10499
10500 Sets the window flag \a flag on this widget if \a on is true;
10501 otherwise clears the flag.
10502
10503 \sa setWindowFlags(), windowFlags(), windowType()
10504*/
10505void QWidget::setWindowFlag(Qt::WindowType flag, bool on)
10506{
10507 Q_D(QWidget);
10508 if (on)
10509 d->setWindowFlags(data->window_flags | flag);
10510 else
10511 d->setWindowFlags(data->window_flags & ~flag);
10512}
10513
10514/*! \internal
10515
10516 Implemented in QWidgetPrivate so that QMdiSubWindowPrivate can reimplement it.
10517*/
10518void QWidgetPrivate::setWindowFlags(Qt::WindowFlags flags)
10519{
10520 Q_Q(QWidget);
10521 if (q->data->window_flags == flags)
10522 return;
10523
10524 if ((q->data->window_flags | flags) & Qt::Window) {
10525 // the old type was a window and/or the new type is a window
10526 QPoint oldPos = q->pos();
10527 bool visible = q->isVisible();
10528 const bool windowFlagChanged = (q->data->window_flags ^ flags) & Qt::Window;
10529 q->setParent(parent: q->parentWidget(), f: flags);
10530
10531 // if both types are windows or neither of them are, we restore
10532 // the old position
10533 if (!windowFlagChanged && (visible || q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_Moved)))
10534 q->move(p: oldPos);
10535 // for backward-compatibility we change Qt::WA_QuitOnClose attribute value only when the window was recreated.
10536 adjustQuitOnCloseAttribute();
10537 } else {
10538 q->data->window_flags = flags;
10539 }
10540}
10541
10542/*!
10543 Sets the window flags for the widget to \a flags,
10544 \e without telling the window system.
10545
10546 \warning Do not call this function unless you really know what
10547 you're doing.
10548
10549 \sa setWindowFlags()
10550*/
10551void QWidget::overrideWindowFlags(Qt::WindowFlags flags)
10552{
10553 data->window_flags = flags;
10554}
10555
10556/*!
10557 \fn Qt::WindowType QWidget::windowType() const
10558
10559 Returns the window type of this widget. This is identical to
10560 windowFlags() & Qt::WindowType_Mask.
10561
10562 \sa windowFlags
10563*/
10564
10565/*!
10566 Sets the parent of the widget to \a parent, and resets the window
10567 flags. The widget is moved to position (0, 0) in its new parent.
10568
10569 If the new parent widget is in a different window, the
10570 reparented widget and its children are appended to the end of the
10571 \l{setFocusPolicy()}{tab chain} of the new parent
10572 widget, in the same internal order as before. If one of the moved
10573 widgets had keyboard focus, setParent() calls clearFocus() for that
10574 widget.
10575
10576 If the new parent widget is in the same window as the
10577 old parent, setting the parent doesn't change the tab order or
10578 keyboard focus.
10579
10580 If the "new" parent widget is the old parent widget, this function
10581 does nothing.
10582
10583 \note The widget becomes invisible as part of changing its parent,
10584 even if it was previously visible. You must call show() to make the
10585 widget visible again.
10586
10587 \warning It is very unlikely that you will ever need this
10588 function. If you have a widget that changes its content
10589 dynamically, it is far easier to use \l QStackedWidget.
10590
10591 \sa setWindowFlags()
10592*/
10593void QWidget::setParent(QWidget *parent)
10594{
10595 if (parent == parentWidget())
10596 return;
10597 setParent(parent: (QWidget*)parent, f: windowFlags() & ~Qt::WindowType_Mask);
10598}
10599
10600static void sendWindowChangeToTextureChildrenRecursively(QWidget *widget, QEvent::Type eventType)
10601{
10602 QWidgetPrivate *d = QWidgetPrivate::get(w: widget);
10603 if (d->renderToTexture) {
10604 QEvent e(eventType);
10605 QCoreApplication::sendEvent(receiver: widget, event: &e);
10606 }
10607
10608 for (int i = 0; i < d->children.size(); ++i) {
10609 QWidget *w = qobject_cast<QWidget *>(o: d->children.at(i));
10610 if (w && !w->isWindow() && QWidgetPrivate::get(w)->textureChildSeen)
10611 sendWindowChangeToTextureChildrenRecursively(widget: w, eventType);
10612 }
10613}
10614
10615/*!
10616 \overload
10617
10618 This function also takes widget flags, \a f as an argument.
10619*/
10620
10621void QWidget::setParent(QWidget *parent, Qt::WindowFlags f)
10622{
10623 Q_D(QWidget);
10624 Q_ASSERT_X(this != parent, Q_FUNC_INFO, "Cannot parent a QWidget to itself");
10625#ifdef QT_DEBUG
10626 const auto checkForParentChildLoops = qScopeGuard([&](){
10627 int depth = 0;
10628 auto p = parentWidget();
10629 while (p) {
10630 if (++depth == QObjectPrivate::CheckForParentChildLoopsWarnDepth) {
10631 qWarning("QWidget %p (class: '%s', object name: '%s') may have a loop in its parent-child chain; "
10632 "this is undefined behavior",
10633 this, metaObject()->className(), qPrintable(objectName()));
10634 }
10635 p = p->parentWidget();
10636 }
10637 });
10638#endif
10639
10640 const bool resized = testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_Resized);
10641 const bool wasCreated = testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WState_Created);
10642 QWidget *oldtlw = window();
10643
10644 if (f & Qt::Window) // Frame geometry likely changes, refresh.
10645 d->data.fstrut_dirty = true;
10646
10647 QWidget *desktopWidget = nullptr;
10648 if (parent && parent->windowType() == Qt::Desktop)
10649 desktopWidget = parent;
10650 bool newParent = (parent != parentWidget()) || desktopWidget;
10651
10652 if (newParent && parent && !desktopWidget) {
10653 if (testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_NativeWindow) && !QCoreApplication::testAttribute(attribute: Qt::AA_DontCreateNativeWidgetSiblings))
10654 parent->d_func()->enforceNativeChildren();
10655 else if (parent->d_func()->nativeChildrenForced() || parent->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_PaintOnScreen))
10656 setAttribute(Qt::WA_NativeWindow);
10657 }
10658
10659 if (wasCreated) {
10660 if (!testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WState_Hidden)) {
10661 hide();
10662 setAttribute(Qt::WA_WState_ExplicitShowHide, on: false);
10663 }
10664 if (newParent) {
10665 QEvent e(QEvent::ParentAboutToChange);
10666 QCoreApplication::sendEvent(receiver: this, event: &e);
10667 }
10668 }
10669
10670 // texture-based widgets need a pre-notification when their associated top-level window changes
10671 // This is not under the wasCreated/newParent conditions above in order to also play nice with QDockWidget.
10672 if (d->textureChildSeen && ((!parent && parentWidget()) || (parent && parent->window() != oldtlw)))
10673 sendWindowChangeToTextureChildrenRecursively(widget: this, eventType: QEvent::WindowAboutToChangeInternal);
10674
10675 // If we get parented into another window, children will be folded
10676 // into the new parent's focus chain, so clear focus now.
10677 if (newParent && isAncestorOf(child: focusWidget()) && !(f & Qt::Window))
10678 focusWidget()->clearFocus();
10679
10680 d->setParent_sys(parent, f);
10681
10682 if (desktopWidget)
10683 parent = nullptr;
10684
10685 if (d->textureChildSeen && parent) {
10686 // set the textureChildSeen flag up the whole parent chain
10687 QWidgetPrivate::get(w: parent)->setTextureChildSeen();
10688 }
10689
10690 if (QWidgetRepaintManager *oldPaintManager = oldtlw->d_func()->maybeRepaintManager()) {
10691 if (newParent)
10692 oldPaintManager->removeDirtyWidget(w: this);
10693 // Move the widget and all its static children from
10694 // the old backing store to the new one.
10695 oldPaintManager->moveStaticWidgets(reparented: this);
10696 }
10697
10698 d->reparentFocusWidgets(oldtlw);
10699 setAttribute(Qt::WA_Resized, on: resized);
10700
10701 const bool useStyleSheetPropagationInWidgetStyles =
10702 QCoreApplication::testAttribute(attribute: Qt::AA_UseStyleSheetPropagationInWidgetStyles);
10703
10704 if (!useStyleSheetPropagationInWidgetStyles && !testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_StyleSheet)
10705 && (!parent || !parent->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_StyleSheet))) {
10706 // if the parent has a font set or inherited, then propagate the mask to the new child
10707 if (parent) {
10708 const auto pd = parent->d_func();
10709 d->inheritedFontResolveMask = pd->directFontResolveMask | pd->inheritedFontResolveMask;
10710 d->inheritedPaletteResolveMask = pd->directPaletteResolveMask | pd->inheritedPaletteResolveMask;
10711 }
10712 d->resolveFont();
10713 d->resolvePalette();
10714 }
10715 d->resolveLayoutDirection();
10716 d->resolveLocale();
10717
10718 // Note: GL widgets under WGL or EGL will always need a ParentChange
10719 // event to handle recreation/rebinding of the GL context, hence the
10720 // (f & Qt::MSWindowsOwnDC) clause (which is set on QGLWidgets on all
10721 // platforms).
10722 if (newParent || !wasCreated
10723#if QT_CONFIG(opengles2)
10724 || (f & Qt::MSWindowsOwnDC)
10725#endif
10726 ) {
10727 // propagate enabled updates enabled state to non-windows
10728 if (!isWindow()) {
10729 if (!testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_ForceDisabled))
10730 d->setEnabled_helper(parent ? parent->isEnabled() : true);
10731 if (!testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_ForceUpdatesDisabled))
10732 d->setUpdatesEnabled_helper(parent ? parent->updatesEnabled() : true);
10733 }
10734 d->inheritStyle();
10735
10736 // send and post remaining QObject events
10737 if (parent && d->sendChildEvents) {
10738 QChildEvent e(QEvent::ChildAdded, this);
10739 QCoreApplication::sendEvent(receiver: parent, event: &e);
10740 }
10741
10742 if (parent && d->sendChildEvents && d->polished) {
10743 QChildEvent e(QEvent::ChildPolished, this);
10744 QCoreApplication::sendEvent(receiver: parent, event: &e);
10745 }
10746
10747 QEvent e(QEvent::ParentChange);
10748 QCoreApplication::sendEvent(receiver: this, event: &e);
10749 }
10750
10751 // texture-based widgets need another event when their top-level window
10752 // changes (more precisely, has already changed at this point)
10753 if (d->textureChildSeen && oldtlw != window())
10754 sendWindowChangeToTextureChildrenRecursively(widget: this, eventType: QEvent::WindowChangeInternal);
10755
10756 if (!wasCreated) {
10757 if (isWindow() || parentWidget()->isVisible())
10758 setAttribute(Qt::WA_WState_Hidden, on: true);
10759 else if (!testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WState_ExplicitShowHide))
10760 setAttribute(Qt::WA_WState_Hidden, on: false);
10761 }
10762
10763 d->updateIsOpaque();
10764
10765#if QT_CONFIG(graphicsview)
10766 // Embed the widget into a proxy if the parent is embedded.
10767 // ### Doesn't handle reparenting out of an embedded widget.
10768 if (oldtlw->graphicsProxyWidget()) {
10769 if (QGraphicsProxyWidget *ancestorProxy = d->nearestGraphicsProxyWidget(origin: oldtlw))
10770 ancestorProxy->d_func()->unembedSubWindow(this);
10771 }
10772 if (isWindow() && parent && !graphicsProxyWidget() && !bypassGraphicsProxyWidget(p: this)) {
10773 if (QGraphicsProxyWidget *ancestorProxy = d->nearestGraphicsProxyWidget(origin: parent))
10774 ancestorProxy->d_func()->embedSubWindow(this);
10775 }
10776#endif
10777
10778 if (d->extra && d->extra->hasWindowContainer)
10779 QWindowContainer::parentWasChanged(parent: this);
10780
10781 QWidget *newtlw = window();
10782 if (oldtlw != newtlw) {
10783 QSurface::SurfaceType surfaceType = QSurface::RasterSurface;
10784 // Only evaluate the reparented subtree. While it might be tempting to
10785 // do it on newtlw instead, the performance implications of that are
10786 // problematic when it comes to large widget trees.
10787 if (q_evaluateRhiConfig(w: this, outConfig: nullptr, outType: &surfaceType)) {
10788 newtlw->d_func()->usesRhiFlush = true;
10789 if (QWindow *w = newtlw->windowHandle()) {
10790 if (w->surfaceType() != surfaceType) {
10791 newtlw->destroy();
10792 newtlw->create();
10793 }
10794 }
10795 }
10796 }
10797}
10798
10799void QWidgetPrivate::setParent_sys(QWidget *newparent, Qt::WindowFlags f)
10800{
10801 Q_Q(QWidget);
10802
10803 Qt::WindowFlags oldFlags = data.window_flags;
10804 bool wasCreated = q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WState_Created);
10805
10806 QScreen *targetScreen = nullptr;
10807 // Handle a request to move the widget to a particular screen
10808 if (newparent && newparent->windowType() == Qt::Desktop) {
10809 // make sure the widget is created on the same screen as the
10810 // programmer specified desktop widget
10811 targetScreen = newparent->screen();
10812 newparent = nullptr;
10813 }
10814
10815 setWinId(0);
10816
10817 if (parent != newparent) {
10818 QObjectPrivate::setParent_helper(newparent); //### why does this have to be done in the _sys function???
10819 if (q->windowHandle()) {
10820 q->windowHandle()->setFlags(f);
10821 QWidget *parentWithWindow =
10822 newparent ? (newparent->windowHandle() ? newparent : newparent->nativeParentWidget()) : nullptr;
10823 if (parentWithWindow) {
10824 QWidget *topLevel = parentWithWindow->window();
10825 if ((f & Qt::Window) && topLevel && topLevel->windowHandle()) {
10826 q->windowHandle()->setTransientParent(topLevel->windowHandle());
10827 q->windowHandle()->setParent(nullptr);
10828 } else {
10829 q->windowHandle()->setTransientParent(nullptr);
10830 q->windowHandle()->setParent(parentWithWindow->windowHandle());
10831 }
10832 } else {
10833 q->windowHandle()->setTransientParent(nullptr);
10834 q->windowHandle()->setParent(nullptr);
10835 }
10836 }
10837 }
10838
10839 if (!newparent) {
10840 f |= Qt::Window;
10841 if (parent)
10842 targetScreen = q->parentWidget()->window()->screen();
10843 }
10844
10845 bool explicitlyHidden = q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WState_Hidden) && q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WState_ExplicitShowHide);
10846
10847 // Reparenting toplevel to child
10848 if (wasCreated && !(f & Qt::Window) && (oldFlags & Qt::Window) && !q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_NativeWindow)) {
10849 if (extra && extra->hasWindowContainer)
10850 QWindowContainer::toplevelAboutToBeDestroyed(parent: q);
10851
10852 QWindow *newParentWindow = newparent->windowHandle();
10853 if (!newParentWindow)
10854 if (QWidget *npw = newparent->nativeParentWidget())
10855 newParentWindow = npw->windowHandle();
10856
10857 for (QObject *child : q->windowHandle()->children()) {
10858 QWindow *childWindow = qobject_cast<QWindow *>(o: child);
10859 if (!childWindow)
10860 continue;
10861
10862 QWidgetWindow *childWW = qobject_cast<QWidgetWindow *>(object: childWindow);
10863 QWidget *childWidget = childWW ? childWW->widget() : nullptr;
10864 if (!childWW || (childWidget && childWidget->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_NativeWindow)))
10865 childWindow->setParent(newParentWindow);
10866 }
10867 q->destroy();
10868 }
10869
10870 adjustFlags(flags&: f, w: q);
10871 data.window_flags = f;
10872 q->setAttribute(Qt::WA_WState_Created, on: false);
10873 q->setAttribute(Qt::WA_WState_Visible, on: false);
10874 q->setAttribute(Qt::WA_WState_Hidden, on: false);
10875
10876 if (newparent && wasCreated && (q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_NativeWindow) || (f & Qt::Window)))
10877 q->createWinId();
10878
10879 if (q->isWindow() || (!newparent || newparent->isVisible()) || explicitlyHidden)
10880 q->setAttribute(Qt::WA_WState_Hidden);
10881 q->setAttribute(Qt::WA_WState_ExplicitShowHide, on: explicitlyHidden);
10882
10883 // move the window to the selected screen
10884 if (!newparent && targetScreen) {
10885 // only if it is already created
10886 if (q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WState_Created))
10887 q->windowHandle()->setScreen(targetScreen);
10888 else
10889 topData()->initialScreen = targetScreen;
10890 }
10891}
10892
10893/*!
10894 Scrolls the widget including its children \a dx pixels to the
10895 right and \a dy downward. Both \a dx and \a dy may be negative.
10896
10897 After scrolling, the widgets will receive paint events for
10898 the areas that need to be repainted. For widgets that Qt knows to
10899 be opaque, this is only the newly exposed parts.
10900 For example, if an opaque widget is scrolled 8 pixels to the left,
10901 only an 8-pixel wide stripe at the right edge needs updating.
10902
10903 Since widgets propagate the contents of their parents by default,
10904 you need to set the \l autoFillBackground property, or use
10905 setAttribute() to set the Qt::WA_OpaquePaintEvent attribute, to make
10906 a widget opaque.
10907
10908 For widgets that use contents propagation, a scroll will cause an
10909 update of the entire scroll area.
10910
10911 \sa {Transparency and Double Buffering}
10912*/
10913
10914void QWidget::scroll(int dx, int dy)
10915{
10916 if ((!updatesEnabled() && children().size() == 0) || !isVisible())
10917 return;
10918 if (dx == 0 && dy == 0)
10919 return;
10920 Q_D(QWidget);
10921#if QT_CONFIG(graphicsview)
10922 if (QGraphicsProxyWidget *proxy = QWidgetPrivate::nearestGraphicsProxyWidget(origin: this)) {
10923 // Graphics View maintains its own dirty region as a list of rects;
10924 // until we can connect item updates directly to the view, we must
10925 // separately add a translated dirty region.
10926 for (const QRect &rect : d->dirty)
10927 proxy->update(rect: rect.translated(dx, dy));
10928 proxy->scroll(dx, dy, rect: proxy->subWidgetRect(widget: this));
10929 return;
10930 }
10931#endif
10932 d->setDirtyOpaqueRegion();
10933 d->scroll_sys(dx, dy);
10934}
10935
10936void QWidgetPrivate::scroll_sys(int dx, int dy)
10937{
10938 Q_Q(QWidget);
10939 scrollChildren(dx, dy);
10940 scrollRect(q->rect(), dx, dy);
10941}
10942
10943/*!
10944 \overload
10945
10946 This version only scrolls \a r and does not move the children of
10947 the widget.
10948
10949 If \a r is empty or invalid, the result is undefined.
10950
10951 \sa QScrollArea
10952*/
10953void QWidget::scroll(int dx, int dy, const QRect &r)
10954{
10955
10956 if ((!updatesEnabled() && children().size() == 0) || !isVisible())
10957 return;
10958 if (dx == 0 && dy == 0)
10959 return;
10960 Q_D(QWidget);
10961#if QT_CONFIG(graphicsview)
10962 if (QGraphicsProxyWidget *proxy = QWidgetPrivate::nearestGraphicsProxyWidget(origin: this)) {
10963 // Graphics View maintains its own dirty region as a list of rects;
10964 // until we can connect item updates directly to the view, we must
10965 // separately add a translated dirty region.
10966 if (!d->dirty.isEmpty()) {
10967 for (const QRect &rect : d->dirty.translated(dx, dy) & r)
10968 proxy->update(rect);
10969 }
10970 proxy->scroll(dx, dy, rect: r.translated(p: proxy->subWidgetRect(widget: this).topLeft().toPoint()));
10971 return;
10972 }
10973#endif
10974 d->scroll_sys(dx, dy, r);
10975}
10976
10977void QWidgetPrivate::scroll_sys(int dx, int dy, const QRect &r)
10978{
10979 scrollRect(r, dx, dy);
10980}
10981
10982/*!
10983 Repaints the widget directly by calling paintEvent() immediately,
10984 unless updates are disabled or the widget is hidden.
10985
10986 We suggest only using repaint() if you need an immediate repaint,
10987 for example during animation. In almost all circumstances update()
10988 is better, as it permits Qt to optimize for speed and minimize
10989 flicker.
10990
10991 \warning If you call repaint() in a function which may itself be
10992 called from paintEvent(), you may get infinite recursion. The
10993 update() function never causes recursion.
10994
10995 \sa update(), paintEvent(), setUpdatesEnabled()
10996*/
10997
10998void QWidget::repaint()
10999{
11000 repaint(rect());
11001}
11002
11003/*! \overload
11004
11005 This version repaints a rectangle (\a x, \a y, \a w, \a h) inside
11006 the widget.
11007
11008 If \a w is negative, it is replaced with \c{width() - x}, and if
11009 \a h is negative, it is replaced width \c{height() - y}.
11010*/
11011void QWidget::repaint(int x, int y, int w, int h)
11012{
11013 if (x > data->crect.width() || y > data->crect.height())
11014 return;
11015
11016 if (w < 0)
11017 w = data->crect.width() - x;
11018 if (h < 0)
11019 h = data->crect.height() - y;
11020
11021 repaint(QRect(x, y, w, h));
11022}
11023
11024/*! \overload
11025
11026 This version repaints a rectangle \a rect inside the widget.
11027*/
11028void QWidget::repaint(const QRect &rect)
11029{
11030 Q_D(QWidget);
11031 d->repaint(t: rect);
11032}
11033
11034/*!
11035 \overload
11036
11037 This version repaints a region \a rgn inside the widget.
11038*/
11039void QWidget::repaint(const QRegion &rgn)
11040{
11041 Q_D(QWidget);
11042 d->repaint(t: rgn);
11043}
11044
11045template <typename T>
11046void QWidgetPrivate::repaint(T r)
11047{
11048 Q_Q(QWidget);
11049
11050 if (!q->isVisible() || !q->updatesEnabled() || r.isEmpty())
11051 return;
11052
11053 QTLWExtra *tlwExtra = q->window()->d_func()->maybeTopData();
11054 if (tlwExtra && tlwExtra->backingStore && tlwExtra->repaintManager)
11055 tlwExtra->repaintManager->markDirty(r, q, QWidgetRepaintManager::UpdateNow);
11056}
11057
11058/*!
11059 Updates the widget unless updates are disabled or the widget is
11060 hidden.
11061
11062 This function does not cause an immediate repaint; instead it
11063 schedules a paint event for processing when Qt returns to the main
11064 event loop. This permits Qt to optimize for more speed and less
11065 flicker than a call to repaint() does.
11066
11067 Calling update() several times normally results in just one
11068 paintEvent() call.
11069
11070 Qt normally erases the widget's area before the paintEvent() call.
11071 If the Qt::WA_OpaquePaintEvent widget attribute is set, the widget is
11072 responsible for painting all its pixels with an opaque color.
11073
11074 \sa repaint(), paintEvent(), setUpdatesEnabled(), {Analog Clock}
11075*/
11076void QWidget::update()
11077{
11078 update(rect());
11079}
11080
11081/*! \fn void QWidget::update(int x, int y, int w, int h)
11082 \overload
11083
11084 This version updates a rectangle (\a x, \a y, \a w, \a h) inside
11085 the widget.
11086*/
11087
11088/*!
11089 \overload
11090
11091 This version updates a rectangle \a rect inside the widget.
11092*/
11093void QWidget::update(const QRect &rect)
11094{
11095 Q_D(QWidget);
11096 d->update(t: rect);
11097}
11098
11099/*!
11100 \overload
11101
11102 This version repaints a region \a rgn inside the widget.
11103*/
11104void QWidget::update(const QRegion &rgn)
11105{
11106 Q_D(QWidget);
11107 d->update(t: rgn);
11108}
11109
11110template <typename T>
11111void QWidgetPrivate::update(T r)
11112{
11113 Q_Q(QWidget);
11114
11115 if (renderToTexture && !q->isVisible()) {
11116 renderToTextureReallyDirty = 1;
11117 return;
11118 }
11119
11120 if (!q->isVisible() || !q->updatesEnabled())
11121 return;
11122
11123 T clipped = r & q->rect();
11124
11125 if (clipped.isEmpty())
11126 return;
11127
11128 if (q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WState_InPaintEvent)) {
11129 QCoreApplication::postEvent(receiver: q, event: new QUpdateLaterEvent(clipped));
11130 return;
11131 }
11132
11133 QTLWExtra *tlwExtra = q->window()->d_func()->maybeTopData();
11134 if (tlwExtra && tlwExtra->backingStore && tlwExtra->repaintManager)
11135 tlwExtra->repaintManager->markDirty(clipped, q);
11136}
11137
11138 /*!
11139 \internal
11140
11141 This just sets the corresponding attribute bit to 1 or 0
11142 */
11143static void setAttribute_internal(Qt::WidgetAttribute attribute, bool on, QWidgetData *data,
11144 QWidgetPrivate *d)
11145{
11146 if (attribute < int(8*sizeof(uint))) {
11147 if (on)
11148 data->widget_attributes |= (1<<attribute);
11149 else
11150 data->widget_attributes &= ~(1<<attribute);
11151 } else {
11152 const int x = attribute - 8*sizeof(uint);
11153 const int int_off = x / (8*sizeof(uint));
11154 if (on)
11155 d->high_attributes[int_off] |= (1<<(x-(int_off*8*sizeof(uint))));
11156 else
11157 d->high_attributes[int_off] &= ~(1<<(x-(int_off*8*sizeof(uint))));
11158 }
11159}
11160
11161#ifdef Q_OS_MAC
11162void QWidgetPrivate::macUpdateSizeAttribute()
11163{
11164 Q_Q(QWidget);
11165 QEvent event(QEvent::MacSizeChange);
11166 QCoreApplication::sendEvent(q, &event);
11167 for (int i = 0; i < children.size(); ++i) {
11168 QWidget *w = qobject_cast<QWidget *>(children.at(i));
11169 if (w && (!w->isWindow() || w->testAttribute(Qt::WA_WindowPropagation))
11170 && !w->testAttribute(Qt::WA_MacMiniSize) // no attribute set? inherit from parent
11171 && !w->testAttribute(Qt::WA_MacSmallSize)
11172 && !w->testAttribute(Qt::WA_MacNormalSize))
11173 w->d_func()->macUpdateSizeAttribute();
11174 }
11175 resolveFont();
11176}
11177#endif
11178
11179/*!
11180 Sets the attribute \a attribute on this widget if \a on is true;
11181 otherwise clears the attribute.
11182
11183 \sa testAttribute()
11184*/
11185void QWidget::setAttribute(Qt::WidgetAttribute attribute, bool on)
11186{
11187 if (testAttribute(attribute) == on)
11188 return;
11189
11190 Q_D(QWidget);
11191 static_assert(sizeof(d->high_attributes)*8 >= (Qt::WA_AttributeCount - sizeof(uint)*8),
11192 "QWidget::setAttribute(WidgetAttribute, bool): "
11193 "QWidgetPrivate::high_attributes[] too small to contain all attributes in WidgetAttribute");
11194#ifdef Q_OS_WIN
11195 // ### Don't use PaintOnScreen+paintEngine() to do native painting in some future release
11196 if (attribute == Qt::WA_PaintOnScreen && on && windowType() != Qt::Desktop && !inherits("QGLWidget")) {
11197 // see ::paintEngine for details
11198 paintEngine();
11199 if (d->noPaintOnScreen)
11200 return;
11201 }
11202#endif
11203
11204 // Don't set WA_NativeWindow on platforms that don't support it -- except for QGLWidget, which depends on it
11205 if (attribute == Qt::WA_NativeWindow && !d->mustHaveWindowHandle) {
11206 QPlatformIntegration *platformIntegration = QGuiApplicationPrivate::platformIntegration();
11207 if (!platformIntegration->hasCapability(cap: QPlatformIntegration::NativeWidgets))
11208 return;
11209 }
11210
11211 setAttribute_internal(attribute, on, data, d);
11212
11213 switch (attribute) {
11214
11215#if QT_CONFIG(draganddrop)
11216 case Qt::WA_AcceptDrops: {
11217 if (on && !testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_DropSiteRegistered))
11218 setAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_DropSiteRegistered, on: true);
11219 else if (!on && (isWindow() || !parentWidget() || !parentWidget()->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_DropSiteRegistered)))
11220 setAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_DropSiteRegistered, on: false);
11221 QEvent e(QEvent::AcceptDropsChange);
11222 QCoreApplication::sendEvent(receiver: this, event: &e);
11223 break;
11224 }
11225 case Qt::WA_DropSiteRegistered: {
11226 for (int i = 0; i < d->children.size(); ++i) {
11227 QWidget *w = qobject_cast<QWidget *>(o: d->children.at(i));
11228 if (w && !w->isWindow() && !w->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_AcceptDrops) && w->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_DropSiteRegistered) != on)
11229 w->setAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_DropSiteRegistered, on);
11230 }
11231 break;
11232 }
11233#endif
11234
11235 case Qt::WA_NoChildEventsForParent:
11236 d->sendChildEvents = !on;
11237 break;
11238 case Qt::WA_NoChildEventsFromChildren:
11239 d->receiveChildEvents = !on;
11240 break;
11241 case Qt::WA_MacNormalSize:
11242 case Qt::WA_MacSmallSize:
11243 case Qt::WA_MacMiniSize:
11244#ifdef Q_OS_MAC
11245 {
11246 // We can only have one of these set at a time
11247 const Qt::WidgetAttribute MacSizes[] = { Qt::WA_MacNormalSize, Qt::WA_MacSmallSize,
11248 Qt::WA_MacMiniSize };
11249 for (int i = 0; i < 3; ++i) {
11250 if (MacSizes[i] != attribute)
11251 setAttribute_internal(MacSizes[i], false, data, d);
11252 }
11253 d->macUpdateSizeAttribute();
11254 }
11255#endif
11256 break;
11257 case Qt::WA_ShowModal:
11258 if (!on) {
11259 // reset modality type to NonModal when clearing WA_ShowModal
11260 data->window_modality = Qt::NonModal;
11261 } else if (data->window_modality == Qt::NonModal) {
11262 // If modality hasn't been set prior to setting WA_ShowModal, use
11263 // ApplicationModal.
11264 data->window_modality = Qt::ApplicationModal;
11265 // Some window managers do not allow us to enter modality after the
11266 // window is visible.The window must be hidden before changing the
11267 // windowModality property and then reshown.
11268 }
11269 if (testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WState_Created)) {
11270 // don't call setModal_sys() before create()
11271 d->setModal_sys();
11272 }
11273 break;
11274 case Qt::WA_MouseTracking: {
11275 QEvent e(QEvent::MouseTrackingChange);
11276 QCoreApplication::sendEvent(receiver: this, event: &e);
11277 break; }
11278 case Qt::WA_TabletTracking: {
11279 QEvent e(QEvent::TabletTrackingChange);
11280 QCoreApplication::sendEvent(receiver: this, event: &e);
11281 break; }
11282 case Qt::WA_NativeWindow: {
11283 d->createTLExtra();
11284 if (on)
11285 d->createTLSysExtra();
11286#ifndef QT_NO_IM
11287 QWidget *focusWidget = d->effectiveFocusWidget();
11288 if (on && !internalWinId() && this == QGuiApplication::focusObject()
11289 && focusWidget->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_InputMethodEnabled)) {
11290 QGuiApplication::inputMethod()->commit();
11291 QGuiApplication::inputMethod()->update(queries: Qt::ImEnabled);
11292 }
11293 if (!QCoreApplication::testAttribute(attribute: Qt::AA_DontCreateNativeWidgetSiblings) && parentWidget())
11294 parentWidget()->d_func()->enforceNativeChildren();
11295 if (on && !internalWinId() && testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WState_Created))
11296 d->createWinId();
11297 if (isEnabled() && focusWidget->isEnabled() && this == QGuiApplication::focusObject()
11298 && focusWidget->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_InputMethodEnabled)) {
11299 QGuiApplication::inputMethod()->update(queries: Qt::ImEnabled);
11300 }
11301#endif //QT_NO_IM
11302 break;
11303 }
11304 case Qt::WA_PaintOnScreen:
11305 d->updateIsOpaque();
11306 Q_FALLTHROUGH();
11307 case Qt::WA_OpaquePaintEvent:
11308 d->updateIsOpaque();
11309 break;
11310 case Qt::WA_NoSystemBackground:
11311 d->updateIsOpaque();
11312 Q_FALLTHROUGH();
11313 case Qt::WA_UpdatesDisabled:
11314 d->updateSystemBackground();
11315 break;
11316 case Qt::WA_TransparentForMouseEvents:
11317 break;
11318 case Qt::WA_InputMethodEnabled: {
11319#ifndef QT_NO_IM
11320 if (QGuiApplication::focusObject() == this) {
11321 if (!on)
11322 QGuiApplication::inputMethod()->commit();
11323 QGuiApplication::inputMethod()->update(queries: Qt::ImEnabled);
11324 }
11325#endif //QT_NO_IM
11326 break;
11327 }
11328 case Qt::WA_WindowPropagation:
11329 d->resolvePalette();
11330 d->resolveFont();
11331 d->resolveLocale();
11332 break;
11333 case Qt::WA_DontShowOnScreen: {
11334 if (on && isVisible()) {
11335 // Make sure we keep the current state and only hide the widget
11336 // from the desktop. show_sys will only update platform specific
11337 // attributes at this point.
11338 d->hide_sys();
11339 d->show_sys();
11340 }
11341 break;
11342 }
11343
11344 case Qt::WA_X11NetWmWindowTypeDesktop:
11345 case Qt::WA_X11NetWmWindowTypeDock:
11346 case Qt::WA_X11NetWmWindowTypeToolBar:
11347 case Qt::WA_X11NetWmWindowTypeMenu:
11348 case Qt::WA_X11NetWmWindowTypeUtility:
11349 case Qt::WA_X11NetWmWindowTypeSplash:
11350 case Qt::WA_X11NetWmWindowTypeDialog:
11351 case Qt::WA_X11NetWmWindowTypeDropDownMenu:
11352 case Qt::WA_X11NetWmWindowTypePopupMenu:
11353 case Qt::WA_X11NetWmWindowTypeToolTip:
11354 case Qt::WA_X11NetWmWindowTypeNotification:
11355 case Qt::WA_X11NetWmWindowTypeCombo:
11356 case Qt::WA_X11NetWmWindowTypeDND:
11357 d->setNetWmWindowTypes();
11358 break;
11359
11360 case Qt::WA_StaticContents:
11361 if (QWidgetRepaintManager *repaintManager = d->maybeRepaintManager()) {
11362 if (on)
11363 repaintManager->addStaticWidget(widget: this);
11364 else
11365 repaintManager->removeStaticWidget(widget: this);
11366 }
11367 break;
11368 case Qt::WA_TranslucentBackground:
11369 if (on)
11370 setAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_NoSystemBackground);
11371 d->updateIsTranslucent();
11372
11373 break;
11374 case Qt::WA_AcceptTouchEvents:
11375 break;
11376 default:
11377 break;
11378 }
11379}
11380
11381/*! \fn bool QWidget::testAttribute(Qt::WidgetAttribute attribute) const
11382
11383 Returns \c true if attribute \a attribute is set on this widget;
11384 otherwise returns \c false.
11385
11386 \sa setAttribute()
11387 */
11388bool QWidget::testAttribute_helper(Qt::WidgetAttribute attribute) const
11389{
11390 Q_D(const QWidget);
11391 const int x = attribute - 8*sizeof(uint);
11392 const int int_off = x / (8*sizeof(uint));
11393 return (d->high_attributes[int_off] & (1<<(x-(int_off*8*sizeof(uint)))));
11394}
11395
11396/*!
11397 \property QWidget::windowOpacity
11398
11399 \brief The level of opacity for the window.
11400
11401 The valid range of opacity is from 1.0 (completely opaque) to
11402 0.0 (completely transparent).
11403
11404 By default the value of this property is 1.0.
11405
11406 This feature is available on Embedded Linux, \macos, Windows,
11407 and X11 platforms that support the Composite extension.
11408
11409 \note On X11 you need to have a composite manager running,
11410 and the X11 specific _NET_WM_WINDOW_OPACITY atom needs to be
11411 supported by the window manager you are using.
11412
11413 \warning Changing this property from opaque to transparent might issue a
11414 paint event that needs to be processed before the window is displayed
11415 correctly. This affects mainly the use of QScreen::grabWindow(). Also note
11416 that semi-transparent windows update and resize significantly slower than
11417 opaque windows.
11418
11419 \sa setMask()
11420*/
11421qreal QWidget::windowOpacity() const
11422{
11423 Q_D(const QWidget);
11424 return (isWindow() && d->maybeTopData()) ? d->maybeTopData()->opacity / 255. : 1.0;
11425}
11426
11427void QWidget::setWindowOpacity(qreal opacity)
11428{
11429 Q_D(QWidget);
11430 if (!isWindow())
11431 return;
11432
11433 opacity = qBound(min: qreal(0.0), val: opacity, max: qreal(1.0));
11434 QTLWExtra *extra = d->topData();
11435 extra->opacity = uint(opacity * 255);
11436 setAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WState_WindowOpacitySet);
11437 d->setWindowOpacity_sys(opacity);
11438
11439 if (!testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WState_Created))
11440 return;
11441
11442#if QT_CONFIG(graphicsview)
11443 if (QGraphicsProxyWidget *proxy = graphicsProxyWidget()) {
11444 // Avoid invalidating the cache if set.
11445 if (proxy->cacheMode() == QGraphicsItem::NoCache)
11446 proxy->update();
11447 else if (QGraphicsScene *scene = proxy->scene())
11448 scene->update(rect: proxy->sceneBoundingRect());
11449 return;
11450 }
11451#endif
11452}
11453
11454void QWidgetPrivate::setWindowOpacity_sys(qreal level)
11455{
11456 Q_Q(QWidget);
11457 if (q->windowHandle())
11458 q->windowHandle()->setOpacity(level);
11459}
11460
11461/*!
11462 \property QWidget::windowModified
11463 \brief whether the document shown in the window has unsaved changes
11464
11465 A modified window is a window whose content has changed but has
11466 not been saved to disk. This flag will have different effects
11467 varied by the platform. On \macos the close button will have a
11468 modified look; on other platforms, the window title will have an
11469 '*' (asterisk).
11470
11471 The window title must contain a "[*]" placeholder, which
11472 indicates where the '*' should appear. Normally, it should appear
11473 right after the file name (e.g., "document1.txt[*] - Text
11474 Editor"). If the window isn't modified, the placeholder is simply
11475 removed.
11476
11477 Note that if a widget is set as modified, all its ancestors will
11478 also be set as modified. However, if you call \c
11479 {setWindowModified(false)} on a widget, this will not propagate to
11480 its parent because other children of the parent might have been
11481 modified.
11482
11483 \sa windowTitle, {Qt Widgets - Application Example},
11484 {MDI Example}
11485*/
11486bool QWidget::isWindowModified() const
11487{
11488 return testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WindowModified);
11489}
11490
11491void QWidget::setWindowModified(bool mod)
11492{
11493 Q_D(QWidget);
11494 setAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WindowModified, on: mod);
11495
11496 d->setWindowModified_helper();
11497
11498 QEvent e(QEvent::ModifiedChange);
11499 QCoreApplication::sendEvent(receiver: this, event: &e);
11500}
11501
11502void QWidgetPrivate::setWindowModified_helper()
11503{
11504 Q_Q(QWidget);
11505 QWindow *window = q->windowHandle();
11506 if (!window)
11507 return;
11508 QPlatformWindow *platformWindow = window->handle();
11509 if (!platformWindow)
11510 return;
11511 bool on = q->testAttribute(attribute: Qt::WA_WindowModified);
11512 if (!platformWindow->setWindowModified(on)) {
11513 if (Q_UNLIKELY(on && !q->windowTitle().contains("[*]"_L1)))
11514 qWarning(msg: "QWidget::setWindowModified: The window title does not contain a '[*]' placeholder");
11515 setWindowTitle_helper(q->windowTitle());
11516 setWindowIconText_helper(q->windowIconText());
11517 }
11518}
11519
11520#if QT_CONFIG(tooltip)
11521/*!
11522 \property QWidget::toolTip
11523
11524 \brief the widget's tooltip
11525
11526 Note that by default tooltips are only shown for widgets that are
11527 children of the active window. You can change this behavior by
11528 setting the attribute Qt::WA_AlwaysShowToolTips on the \e window,
11529 not on the widget with the tooltip.
11530
11531 If you want to control a tooltip's behavior, you can intercept the
11532 event() function and catch the QEvent::ToolTip event (e.g., if you
11533 want to customize the area for which the tooltip should be shown).
11534
11535 By default, this property contains an empty string.
11536
11537 \sa QToolTip, statusTip, whatsThis
11538*/
11539void QWidget::setToolTip(const QString &s)
11540{
11541 Q_D(QWidget);
11542 d->toolTip = s;
11543
11544 QEvent event(QEvent::ToolTipChange);
11545 QCoreApplication::sendEvent(receiver: this, event: &event);
11546}
11547
11548QString QWidget::toolTip() const
11549{
11550 Q_D(const QWidget);
11551 return d->toolTip;
11552}
11553
11554/*!
11555 \property QWidget::toolTipDuration
11556 \brief the widget's tooltip duration
11557 \since 5.2
11558
11559 Specifies how long time the tooltip will be displayed, in milliseconds.
11560 If the value is -1 (default) the duration is calculated depending on the length of the tooltip.
11561
11562 \sa toolTip
11563*/
11564
11565void QWidget::setToolTipDuration(int msec)
11566{
11567 Q_D(QWidget);
11568 d->toolTipDuration = msec;
11569}
11570
11571int QWidget::toolTipDuration() const
11572{
11573 Q_D(const QWidget);
11574 return d->toolTipDuration;
11575}
11576
11577#endif // QT_CONFIG(tooltip)
11578
11579
11580#if QT_CONFIG(statustip)

11584
11585 By default, this property contains an empty string.
11586
11587 \sa toolTip, whatsThis
11588*/
11589void QWidget::setStatusTip(const QString &s)
11590{
11591 Q_D(QWidget);
11592 d->statusTip = s;
11593}
11594
11595QString QWidget::statusTip() const
11596{
11597 Q_D(const QWidget);
11598 return d->statusTip;
11599}
11600#endif // QT_CONFIG(statustip)
11601
11602#if QT_CONFIG(whatsthis)
11603/*!
11604 \property QWidget::whatsThis
11605
11606 \brief the widget's What's This help text.
11607
11608 By default, this property contains an empty string.
11609
11610 \sa QWhatsThis, QWidget::toolTip, QWidget::statusTip
11611*/
11612void QWidget::setWhatsThis(const QString &s)
11613{
